question: Question 1 A reinforced concrete beam has a support section with width of 300 mm and effective depth of 500 mm. The support section is reinforced with 3 bars of 20 mm diameter at the tension side. Two-legged vertical stirrups of 10 mm diameter and Fe415 steel at a spacing of 100 mm are provided as shear reinforcement. Assume that there is no possibility of diagonal compression failure at the section. As per IS 456:2000, the maximum shear resisted by the vertical stirrups (in kN), as per limit state design, is ___________ (round off to one decimal place).
solution: Maximum shear resisted by stirrups is given by: [latex]V_{us} = \frac{0.87 \cdot f_y \cdot A_{sv} \cdot d}{s}[/latex] Where: [latex]f_y = 415\ \text{MPa}[/latex] (for Fe415 steel) [latex]A_{sv} = 2 \cdot \frac{\pi}{4} \cdot 10^2 = 157.08\ \text{mm}^2[/latex] (two-legged 10 mm stirrups) [latex]d = 500\ \text{mm}[/latex] [latex]s = 100\ \text{mm}[/latex] Substitute values: [latex]V_{us} = \frac{0.87 \cdot 415 \cdot 157.08 \cdot 500}{100}[/latex] [latex]V_{us} = \frac{(0.87 \cdot 415 \cdot 157.08 \cdot 500)}{100} = \frac{(28302150)}{100} = 283021.5\ \text{N}[/latex] Convert to kN: [latex]V_{us} = \frac{283021.5}{1000} = \boxed{283.0\ \text{kN}}[/latex]

question: Question 2 Consider a reinforced concrete beam section of 350 mm width and 600 mm depth. The beam is reinforced with the tension steel of [latex]800\ \text{mm}^2[/latex] area at an effective cover of 40 mm. Consider M20 concrete and Fe415 steel. Let the stress block considered for concrete in IS 456:2000 be replaced by an equivalent rectangular stress block, with no change in: (a) the area of the stress block, (b) the design strength of concrete (at the strain of 0.0035), and (c) the location of neutral axis at flexural collapse. The ultimate moment of resistance of the beam (in kN.m) is __________________ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Given: [latex]b = 350\ \text{mm}[/latex] [latex]D = 600\ \text{mm}[/latex] [latex]d = 600 - 40 = 560\ \text{mm}[/latex] [latex]A_{st} = 800\ \text{mm}^2[/latex] [latex]f_{ck} = 20\ \text{MPa}[/latex] (M20) [latex]f_y = 415\ \text{MPa}[/latex] (Fe415) As per IS 456:2000, ultimate moment for singly reinforced rectangular section: [latex]M_u = 0.87 f_y A_{st} \left(d - 0.42 x_u \right)[/latex] To find [latex]x_u[/latex], use force equilibrium: [latex]0.36 f_{ck} b x_u = 0.87 f_y A_{st}[/latex] [latex]0.36 \times 20 \times 350 \times x_u = 0.87 \times 415 \times 800[/latex] [latex]2520 x_u = 288360[/latex] [latex]x_u = \frac{288360}{2520} = 114.4\ \text{mm}[/latex] Now calculate [latex]M_u[/latex]: [latex]M_u = 0.87 \times 415 \times 800 \left(560 - 0.42 \times 114.4 \right)[/latex] [latex]M_u = 288360 \times (560 - 48.048) = 288360 \times 511.95[/latex] [latex]M_u = 1.476 \times 10^8\ \text{N.mm}[/latex] [latex]M_u = 147.6\ \text{kN.m} \approx \boxed{148\ \text{kN?m}}[/latex]

question:
Question 3 The design shear strength of a reinforced concrete rectangular beam with a width 
of [latex]250\text{mm}[/latex] and an effective depth of [latex]500\text{mm}[/latex], is [latex]0.3\text{MPa}[/latex]. 
The torsional moment capacity of the section (in kN.m) under pure torsion,
as per IS 456:2000, is ______ (round off to one decimal place).
solution: Given: [latex]b = 250\text{mm}[/latex] [latex]d = 500\text{mm}[/latex] Using empirical torsional stress: [latex]\tau_{eq} = 0.162\text{N/mm}^2[/latex] Apply torsional moment formula (with 1.7 partial factor): [latex]T_c = \tau_{eq} \cdot \left(\frac{1}{1.7}\right) \cdot b \cdot d^2[/latex] Substitute values: [latex]T_c = 0.162 \cdot 0.588 \cdot 250 \cdot 250000 = 5.955 \text{kN.m}[/latex] Answer: [latex]\boxed{6.0 \text{kN.m}}[/latex]

question: Question 4 Consider a reinforced concrete beam section of 300 mm width and 700 mm depth. The beam is reinforced with the tension steel of [latex]2000 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}[/latex] area at an effective cover of 50 mm . Concrete in the tension zone is assumed to be cracked. Assume the modular ratio of 12 and Young's modulus of 200 GPa for steel. When the extreme fibre in the compression zone undergoes the strain of 0.0004 due to the applied bending moment, the stress in the steel (in MPa) is _________ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution: Given: Width of beam, [latex]b = 300 , \text{mm}[/latex] Depth of beam, [latex]D = 700 , \text{mm}[/latex] Effective cover, [latex]d' = 50 , \text{mm}[/latex] ? Effective depth to steel, [latex]d = 700 - 50 = 650 , \text{mm}[/latex] Area of steel, [latex]A_s = 2000 , \text{mm}^2[/latex] Modular ratio, [latex]m = 12[/latex] Young?s modulus of steel, [latex]E_s = 200 , \text{GPa}[/latex] Strain at extreme compression fibre, [latex]\varepsilon_c = 0.0004[/latex] Step 1: Let the neutral axis be at a depth [latex]x[/latex] from the top. By similar triangles from the strain diagram: [latex]\frac{0.0004}{x} = \frac{\varepsilon_s}{650 - x}[/latex] ? [latex]\varepsilon_s = 0.0004 \times \frac{650 - x}{x}[/latex] Step 2: Take moment of area about NA using transformed section Concrete in tension is cracked ? Use equivalent area method: Steel area transformed = [latex]m A_s = 12 \times 2000 = 24000 , \text{mm}^2[/latex] Equating compressive and tensile forces for equilibrium: Compression force = [latex]C = 0.5 \times b \times x \times \varepsilon_c E_c[/latex] Tension force = [latex]T = A_s E_s \varepsilon_s[/latex] But easier to use moments using equivalent area: Step 3: Take moment of area about neutral axis to locate [latex]x[/latex] Moment of compression block about NA: [latex]M_c = b x \times \left(\frac{x}{2}\right) = 300 x \times \frac{x}{2} = 150 x^2[/latex] Moment of steel area about NA: [latex]M_s = m A_s (d - x) = 24000 (650 - x)[/latex] Set total moment of compression and transformed steel equal: [latex]150 x^2 = 24000 (650 - x)[/latex] [latex]150 x^2 + 24000 x - 15600000 = 0[/latex] Divide entire equation by 150: [latex]x^2 + 160 x - 104000 = 0[/latex] Solving using quadratic formula: [latex]x = \frac{-160 \pm \sqrt{160^2 + 4 \times 104000}}{2} = \frac{-160 \pm \sqrt{25600 + 416000}}{2}[/latex] [latex]= \frac{-160 \pm \sqrt{441600}}{2} = \frac{-160 \pm 664.6}{2}[/latex] Taking positive root: [latex]x = \frac{504.6}{2} = 252.3 , \text{mm}[/latex] Step 4: Strain in steel [latex]\varepsilon_s = 0.0004 \times \frac{650 - x}{x} = 0.0004 \times \frac{650 - 252.3}{252.3}[/latex] [latex]= 0.0004 \times \frac{397.7}{252.3} \approx 0.0004 \times 1.576 = 0.0006305[/latex] Step 5: Stress in steel [latex]\sigma_s = E_s \varepsilon_s = 200 \times 10^3 \times 0.0006305 = 126.1 , \text{MPa}[/latex] Final Answer: [latex]\boxed{126 , \text{MPa}}[/latex]

question: Question 5 If the weights retained on the [latex]2.36 \mathrm{~mm}, 1.18 \mathrm{~mm}, 600 \mu \mathrm{~m}[/latex], and [latex]300 \mu \mathrm{~m}[/latex] sieves are [latex]30 \%[/latex], [latex]35 \%, 15 \%[/latex], and [latex]20 \%[/latex], respectively, of the total weight of an aggregate sample, then the fineness modulus of the sample is _________ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: To calculate the Fineness Modulus (FM), we take the cumulative percentage retained on each standard sieve and divide the sum by 100. Given weights retained: On 2.36 mm sieve = 30% On 1.18 mm sieve = 35% On 600 [latex]\mu m[/latex] sieve = 15% On 300 [latex]\mu m[/latex] sieve = 20% Step 1: Compute cumulative percentages retained: - 2.36 mm sieve: [latex] 30\% [/latex] - 1.18 mm sieve: [latex] 30 + 35 = 65\% [/latex] - 600 [latex]\mu m[/latex] sieve: [latex] 65 + 15 = 80\% [/latex] - 300 [latex]\mu m[/latex] sieve: [latex] 80 + 20 = 100\% [/latex] Step 2: Sum of cumulative percentages retained: [latex] 30 + 65 + 80 + 100 = 275 [/latex] Step 3: Fineness Modulus: [latex] \text{FM} = \frac{275}{100} = 2.75 [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{2.75} [/latex]

question: Question 6 As per IS 456:2000 provisions for two-way slabs with continuous edges, the longitudinal steel reinforcement to be provided in the edge strip is based on
solution: As per IS 456:2000, in the design of two-way slabs with continuous edges, the slab is divided into middle strips and edge strips. The bending moment is primarily resisted by the middle strip, while the edge strip is provided mainly for distribution and minimum reinforcement. According to Clause 27.4.3 of IS 456:2000: Reinforcement in the edge strip is not based on calculated moments or reinforcement in the middle strip. Instead, it is based on the prescribed minimum requirement for slabs. Therefore, Reinforcement in edge strip = Prescribed minimum cross-sectional area of longitudinal steel for slabs Final Answer: The prescribed minimum cross-sectional area of longitudinal steel for slabs

options.B: the area of longitudinal steel provided in the middle strip in the shorter span
options.C: the area of longitudinal steel provided in the middle strip in the longer span
options.D: the prescribed minimum cross-sectional area of longitudinal steel for slabs

Question 9 The structural design method that DOES NOT take into account the safety factors on the design load is
solution: In working stress method, safety is accounted for by considering factor of safety in material strength only and no factor is considered in load.

By using Rankine-Grashoff method, the ratio [latex] M_{u x} [/latex] ' [latex] \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{uy}} [/latex] is proportional to

Question 11 A slab panel with an effective depth of [latex]250 \mathrm{~mm} [/latex] is reinforced with [latex]0.2 \% [/latex] main reinforcement using [latex]8 \mathrm{~mm} [/latex] diameter steel bars. The uniform center-to-center spacing (in [latex]\mathrm{mm} [/latex] ) at which the [latex]8 \mathrm{~mm} [/latex] diameter bars are placed in the slab panel is _____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).

Question 12 An inverted T-shaped concrete beam (B1) in the figure, with centroidal axis [latex]X-X [/latex] is subjected to an effective prestressing force of [latex]1000 \mathrm{kN} [/latex] acting at the bottom kern point of the beam cross-section. Also consider an identical concrete beam (B2) with the same grade of concrete but without any prestressing force. The additional cracking moment (in [latex]\mathrm{KNm} [/latex] ) that can be carried by beam [latex]\mathrm{B} 1 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] comparison to beam B2 is ______ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
At bottom fibre, [latex]
\frac{P}{A}+\frac{P e y_{b}}{I}-\frac{M_{c r}}{I} y_{b}=0 \;\;\;...(i)
 [/latex] where [latex]
\begin{aligned}
P & =\text { Prestressing force } \\
e & =\text { Eccentricity of P-force } \\
M_{c r} & =\text { cracking moment for beam B1 }
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] [latex]y_{t} [/latex] and [latex]y_{b} [/latex] are distance of top and bottom fibre from neutral axis respectively, At top fibre [latex]
\frac{P}{A}-\frac{P e y_{t}}{I}=0
 [/latex] [P-force is at kern point] [latex]
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{I}{A}=e y_{t}  \;\;\;...(ii)
 [/latex] Putting (ii) in (i) [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{M_{c r}}{I} y_{b} & =\frac{P}{A}+\frac{P e y_{t}}{I} \\
\Rightarrow \quad M_{c r} & =\frac{P I}{A y_{b}}+P e \\
& =\frac{P e y_{t}}{y_{b}}+P e \\
& =\frac{P e(2 H / 3)}{(H / 3)}+P e \\
& =3 P e=3 \times 1000 \times \frac{100}{1000}=300 \mathrm{kNm}
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

question: Question 13 Consider a balanced doubly reinforced concrete section. If the material and other sectional properties remain unchanged, for which of the following cases will the section becomes under-reinforced?
solution:
In a doubly reinforced balance section, the [latex] A_{st} [/latex] and
[latex] A_{sc} [/latex]  are such that the depth of neutral axis is [latex]x_{u,lim}[/latex]
or [latex]x_{bal}[/latex]. To make the above section an under-reinforced
section, the strength of compression side has to be
increased compared to that of tension side. This can be done by either increasing the amount
of compression reinforcement or decreasing the
amount of tension reinforcement. Hence, the correct options are (B) and (C)

options.A: Area of tension reinforcement is increased.
options.B: Area of compression reinforcement is increased.
options.C: Area of tension reinforcement is decreased.
options.D: Area of compression reinforcement is decreased.

question: Question 14 The following figure shows the arrangement of formwork for casting a cantilever RC beam. The correct sequence of removing the Shores/Props is
solution:
While removing the props, we need to ensure that
the beam type does not change i.e. if it is a
cantilever beam then the props shall be removed in
such a manner that the beam at the intermediate
stage also shows cantilever behaviour. If we remove prop 'S1' first then tensile stress will
be generated at the bottom and no structural
reinforcement is there to take care of this tension. So, correct order is S5 [latex] \rightarrow [/latex]S4 [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] S3 [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] S2 [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] S1

question: Question 15 Concrete of characteristic strength [latex] 30 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] is required. If 40 specimens of concrete cubes are to be tested, the minimum number of specimens having at least [latex] 30 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] strength should be
solution: As per IS456:2000, atleast [latex] 95 \%[/latex]  of the specimen should have strength equal to more than the characteristics strength. [latex]\therefore[/latex]  Minimum number of specimens [latex] =0.95 \times 40=38[/latex]

question: Question 16 Consider the singly reinforced section of a cantilever concrete beam under bending, as shown in the figure (M25 grade concrete, Fe415 grade steel). The stress block parameters for the section at ultimate limit state, as per IS 456: 2000 notations, are given. The ultimate moment of resistance for the section by the Limit State Method is ____ kN.m (round off to one decimal place). [Note: Here, As is the total area of tension steel bars, [latex]b[/latex] is the width of the section, [latex]d[/latex] is the effective depth of the bars, [latex]f_{c k}[/latex] is the characteristic compressive cube strength of concrete, [latex]f_{y}[/latex] is the yield stress of steel, and [latex]\mathrm{xu}[/latex] is the depth of neutral axis.]
solution:
Given data, Grade of concrete [latex]=[/latex] M25 Grade of Steel [latex]=\mathrm{Fe} 415[/latex] Effective depth, [latex]d=600-45=555 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] [latex]
A_{s}=3 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(28)^{2}=1847.26 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}
[/latex] From Compression [latex]=[/latex] Tension Depth of neutral axis, [latex]x_{u}=\frac{0.87 f_{y} A_{s}}{0.36 f_{c k} b}=\frac{0.87 \times 415 \times 1847.26}{0.36 \times 25 \times 300}  =247.02 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] Limiting depth of neutral axis, [latex]x_{u, l i m}=0.48 \mathrm{~d}[/latex]

[latex]
=0.48 \times 555=266.40 \mathrm{~mm}
[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Section is under reinforced. Ultimate moment of resistance [latex]
=0.36 f_{c k} b x_{u}\left(d-0.42 x_{u}\right)
[/latex] [latex]=0.36 \times 25 \times 300 \times 247.02 \times[/latex]

[latex](555-0.42 \times 247.02) \times 10^{-6}[/latex] [latex]=301.0[/latex] (after rounding off to one decimal place).

question: Question 17 Two plates are connected by fillet welds of size 10 [latex]\mathrm{mm}[/latex] and subjected to tension, as shown in the figure. The thickness of each plate is [latex]12 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]. The yield stress and the ultimate stress of steel under tension are [latex]250 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] and [latex]410 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex], respectively. The welding is done in the workshop (partial safety factor, [latex]\gamma_{\mathrm{mw}}=1.25[/latex] ). As per the Limit State Method of IS 800: 2007, what is the minimum length (in [latex]\mathrm{mm}[/latex], rounded off to the nearest higher multiple of [latex]5 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] ) required of each weld to transmit a factored force [latex]P[/latex] equal to [latex]275 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] ?
Question 18 With regard to the shear design of RCC beams, which of the following statements is/are TRUE?
solution: Option A is true, because when the area of shear reinforcement is large i.e. in case of excessive shear reinforcement, concrete becomes stronger is diagonal tension on failure compared to diagonal compression failure and compression failure may occur before the shear reinforcement has yielded. Option '[latex]B[/latex]' is true because for beams without shear reinforcement, once the flexural crack crosses the longitudinal reinforcement, the propagation of crack will be sudden and there can be brittle failure. Option '[latex]C[/latex]' is not true, as main reinforcement increases the shear resitance by providing dowel action, limiting crack width and by increasing the depth of concrete. Design shear strength of concrete is a function of grade of concree and percentage tensile reinforcement. Option 'D' is true, as for beams with varying depth, nominal shear stress, [latex]\tau_{v}=\frac{V_{u} \pm \frac{M_{u} \tan \beta}{d}}{b d}([/latex] clause 40.1.1, IS456: 2000) it is dependent on both the design shear force and design bending moment. Hence, options (A), (B) and (D) are true.

options.A: Excessive shear reinforcement can lead to compression failure in concrete
options.B: Beams without shear reinforcement, even if adequately designed for flexure, can have brittle failure
options.C: The main (longitudinal) reinforcement plays no role in the shear resistance of beam
options.D: As per IS456:2000, the nominal shear stress in the beams of varying depth depends on both the design shear force as well as the design bending moment

question: Question 19 M20 concrete as per IS 456: 2000 refers to concrete with a design mix having
solution: In M20, M refers to mix and 20 to characteristic cube strength. As per clause no. 6.1.1, IS456: 2000 characteristic strength is defined as the strength below which not more than 5 percent of the test results are expected to fall. Hence, correct option is (C).

question: Question 20 Consider a doubly reinforced RCC beam with the option of using either Fe250 plain bars or Fe500 deformed bars in the compression zone. The modulus of elasticity of steel is [latex]2 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex]. As per IS456-2000, in which type(s) of the bars, the stress in the compression steel [latex]\left(f_{s c}\right)[/latex] can reach the design strength [latex]\left(0.87 f_{y}\right)[/latex] at the limit state of collapse?
solution:
In a doubly reinforced beam, at the limit state of collapse. The strain in the extreme corression fibre will be [latex]0.0035[/latex]. As the compression reinforcement will be below this, the strain in if will be always less than [latex]0.0035[/latex]. For Fe250, the yield strain [latex]=\frac{0.87 \times 250}{2 \times 10^{5}}=0.0010875
[/latex] For Fe500, the yield strain [latex]\begin{aligned}
& =0.002+\frac{0.87 \mathrm{f}_{y}}{E_{s}} \\
& =0.002+\frac{0.87 \times 500}{2 \times 10^{5}} \\
& =0.004175>0.0035
\end{aligned}
[/latex] So, it is possible that [latex]\mathrm{Fe} 250[/latex] can reach upto its yield strain and hence can reach the design strength [latex]0.87 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{y}}[/latex].

options.C:
Both Fe250 plain bars and Fe500 deformed
bars
options.D:
Neither Fe250 plain bars nor Fe500 deformed
bars

question: Question 21 In cement concrete mix design, with the increase in water-cement ratio, which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: As the water-cement ratio increases, the porosity in the hardened concrete increases and hence the strength decreases. Also, as water-cement ratio increases, ducts higher water availability, the workability increases. Hence, correct answer is (A).

options.A:
Compressive strength decreases but workability
increase
options.B:
Compressive strength increases but workability
decreases
options.C:
Both compressive strength and workability
decrease
options.D:
Both compressive strength and workability
increase

question:
Question 24 It is given that an aggregate mix has 260 grams of coarse aggregates and
240 grams of fine aggregates. The specific gravities of the coarse and fine
aggregates are 2.6 and 2.4, respectively. The bulk specific gravity of the mix is
2.3. The percentage air voids in the mix is ____________. (round off to the nearest
integer)
solution:
Given that, Coarse aggregate = 260 gms Fine aggregate = 240 gms [latex]G_{CA}=2.6 [/latex] [latex]G_{FA}=2.4 [/latex] Bulk specific gravity [latex]G_m=2.3 [/latex] Percentage air voids in the mix = ? [latex]G_t [/latex] (Theoretical specific gravity) [latex] \begin{aligned}
&=\frac{\Sigma W}{\Sigma \frac{W}{G}}\\
 &=\frac{260+240}{\frac{260}{2.6}+\frac{240}{2.4}}\\
&=2.5
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
% \text{ air voids} (V_V)&=\frac{G_t-G_m}{G_t} \times 100\\
 &=\frac{2.5-2.3}{2.3}\times 100\\
V_V&=8%
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 25 A post-tensioned concrete member of span 15 m and cross-section of
450 mm x 450 mm is prestressed with three steel tendons, each of
cross-sectional area 200 [latex]mm^2[/latex]. The tendons are tensioned one after another
to a stress of 1500 MPa. All the tendons are straight and located at 125 mm
from the bottom of the member. Assume the prestress to be the same in all
tendons and the modular ratio to be 6. The average loss of prestress, due to
elastic deformation of concrete, considering all three tendons is
solution:
This is a question of calculation of elastic
shortening loss in post tensioned member. Given data, length = 15 m b x D = 450 mm x 450 mm Numberof tendons = 3 Cross-section area of each tendon [latex] (A_s)=200 mm^2[/latex]. Prestress = 1500 MPa Modular ratio (m) = 6 From the given data, eccentricity (e) =
450/2-125 = 100 mm Force in each cable [latex](P) = 1500 \times 200 \times 10^{-3} =
300 kN[/latex] The tendons are tensioned one after another, and
hence when tendon (1) is pulled no loss in tenson
(1) When tendon (2) is pulled, loss in tendon (1) but
no loss in tendon (2). When tendon (3) is pulled, loss in tendon (1) and
(2), but no loss in tendon (3). Hence, there will be 2 times losses in tendon (1),
time loss in tendon (1) and no loss in tendon (3). While calculating elastic shortening loss, self
weight of the structure is neglected to be on the conservative side. Consider tensioning of tendon-1 No loss in tendon (1) Consider tensioning of tendon-2 Stress in concrete at the level of prestressing tendon [latex]\begin{aligned}
 f_c&= \frac{P}{A}+\frac{Pe}{I}\\ 
 e&=\frac{300 \times 10^3}{450 \times 450}+\frac{300 \times 10^3 \times 100 \times 100}{\frac{450 \times 450^3}{12}} \\ 
 &= 2.36MPa
\end{aligned} [/latex] I = moment of inertial of the section about the
centroidal axis. As the tendons are horizontal and at the same
level [latex]f_{c,avg} = f_c[/latex]. Loss due to elastic deformation [latex]= mfc
= 6 \times 2.36 = 14.16 MPa.[/latex] Considering tensioning of tendon 3 Loss due to elastic deformation in (1) 
[latex]= mfc
= 6 \times 2.36 = 14.16 MPa.[/latex] Loss due to elastic deformation in (2)
[latex]= mfc
= 6 \times 2.36 = 14.16 MPa.[/latex] Total loss in tendon (1) = 2 x 14.16 = 28.32 MPa Total loss in tendon (1) = 2 x 14.16 = 28.32 MPa In tendon (2) = 14.16 MPa In tendon (3) = 0 Average loss of pre-stress, considering all
three tendons is
[latex] =\frac{28.32+14.16+0}{3}=14.16MPa[/latex]

Question 26 Match all the possible combinations between Column X (Cement compounds) and Column Y (Cement properties): [latex]\begin{array}{|c|l|}\hline
 \text{Column X}&\text{Column Y} \\ \hline
(i) C_3S & \text{(P) Early age strength} \\ \hline
(ii) C_2S & \text{(Q) Later age strength}\\ \hline
 (iii) C_3A& \text{(R) Flash setting}\\ \hline
 & \text{(S) Highest heat of hydration}\\ \hline
 & \text{(T) Lowest heat of hydration}\\ \hline

solution: [latex]C_3S-[/latex] Responsible for early age strength [latex]C_2S - [/latex] Responsible for later age strength and lowest heat of hydration [latex]C_3A- [/latex] Flash setting and highest heat of hydration

question:
Question 27 Read the following statements relating to flexure of reinforced concrete beams: I. In over-reinforced sections, the failure strain in concrete reaches earlier than
the yield strain in steel. II. In under-reinforced sections, steel reaches yielding at a load lower than the
load at which the concrete reaches failure strain. III. Over-reinforced beams are recommended in practice as compared to the
under-reinforced beams. IV. In balanced sections, the concrete reaches failure strain earlier than the yield
strain in tensile steel. Each of the above statements is either True or False. Which one of the following combinations is correct?
solution:
The question is based on LSM design principle
as it is describing different conditions related to
strain Depending on amount of reinforcement in a cross-
section, here ca be three types of sections viz. balanced, under reinforced and over reinforced. Balanced section is a section that is expected to
result in a balanced failure. It means at the ultimate
limit state in flexure, the concrete will attain a
limiting compressive strain of 0.0035 and steel
will attain minimum specified tensile strain of [latex]0.002+\frac{0.87f_y}{E_s}[/latex] Under reinforced section is a section in which
steel yield before collapse.
Over reinforced section is a section in which
crushing of concrete in compression i.e. attainment
of compressive strain of 0.0035 occurs prior to yielding of steel. In case of over reinforced section the deflection,
crack width remain relatively low and failure occurs
without any sign of warning and hence over
reinforced flexural members are not recommended by IS code. Based on the above information: Statement I is true. Statement II is true. Statement III is false. Statement IV is false.

question:
Question 28 A reinforced concrete beam with rectangular cross section (width = 300 mm,
effective depth = 580 mm) is made of [latex]M30[/latex] grade concrete. It has 1%
longitudinal tension reinforcement of [latex]Fe 415[/latex] grade steel. The design shear
strength for this beam is 0.66 [latex]N/mm^2[/latex]. The beam has to resist a factored shear
force of 440 kN. The spacing of two-legged, 10 mm diameter vertical stirrups of
[latex]Fe 415[/latex] grade steel is ______mm. (round off to the nearest integer)
solution:
[latex]b=300mm[/latex] [latex]d=580 mm  [/latex] [latex]V_u=440 kN  [/latex] Concrete used is M30 Raft steel is Fe415 [latex]  V_{cu}=\tau _c Bd=0.66 \times 300 \times \frac{580}{1000}=114.84 kN[/latex] [latex]  V_{su}=V_u-V_{cu}=440-114.84=325.16 kN[/latex] Spacing of 2-legged shear reinforcement [latex] \begin{aligned}
s_V&=\frac{A_{SV} \times 0.87 f_y \times d}{V_{su}}\\
&=\frac{2 \times \frac{\pi}{2} \times (10)^2 \times 0.87 \times 415 \times 580}{325.16 \times 1000}\\
&=101.16 mm
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question: Question 31 A rectangular cross-section of a reinforced concrete beam is shown in the figure. The diameter of each reinforcing bar is 16 mm. The values of modulus of elasticity of concrete and steel are [latex]2.0 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{MPa} \text { and } 2.1 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{MPa}[/latex], respectively. The distance of the centroidal axis from the centerline of the reinforcement (x) for the uncracked section (in mm,round off to one decimal place) is ____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} m&=\frac{E_{s}}{E_{C}}=\frac{2.1 \times 10^{5}}{2 \times 10^{4}}=10.5 \\ A_{s t}&=3 \times \frac{\pi}{4}(16)^{2}=603.20 \mathrm{~mm}^{2} \\ \bar{y}&=\frac{\left(B \cdot D \cdot \frac{D}{2}+(m-1) \times A_{s t} \times d\right)}{B \cdot D+(m-1) \cdot A_{s t}} \\ &=\frac{\left(200 \times \frac{350^{2}}{2}+(10.5-1) \times 603.2 \times 315\right)}{200 \times 350+(10.5-1) \times 603.2}=185.59 \mathrm{~mm}\\ & \text{Distance of N-A from reinforcement}\\ y_{2} &=d-\bar{y} \\ &=315-185.59=129.41 \mathrm{~mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 A combined trapezoidal footing of length L supports two identical square columns  ([latex]P_{1}[/latex] and [latex]P_{2}[/latex]) of size 0.5m x 0.5m, as shown in the figure. The columns [latex]P_{1}[/latex] and [latex]P_{2}[/latex] carry loads of 2000 kN and 1500 kN, respectively. If the stress beneath the footing is uniform, the length of the combined footing L (in m,round off to two decimal places) is _____
solution: C.G. of load from [latex]P_{1}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{R} \bar{x} &=P_{1} \times 0+P_{2} \times 5 \\ \bar{x} &=\frac{1500 \times 5}{3500}=2.143 \mathrm{~m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Distance of C.G. of footing from face of [latex]P_{1}[/latex] [latex]\bar{y}=\bar{x}+0.25=2.393 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] C.G of footing [latex]\begin{aligned} \bar{y} &=\left(\frac{B_{1}+2 B_{2}}{B_{1}+B_{2}}\right) \times \frac{L}{3} \\ 2.393 &=\left(\frac{5+2 \times 1.5}{5+1.5}\right) \times \frac{L}{3} \\ L &=5.833 \mathrm{~m} \text { say } 5.83 \mathrm{~m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 A prismatic cantilever prestressed concrete beam of span length, L=1.5 m has one straight tendon placed in the cross-section as shown in the following figure (not to scale). The total prestressing force of 50 kN in the tendon is applied at [latex]d_{c}=50 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] from the top in the cross-section of width, b=200 mm and depth, d=300 mm. If the concentrated load, P=5 kN, the resultant stress (in Mpa,in integer) experienced at point 'Q' will be _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{e} &=\frac{D}{2}-50=\frac{300}{2}-50=100 \mathrm{~mm} \\ \mathrm{DL} &=0.2 \times 0.3 \times 1.0 \times 25=1.50 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \\ P &=50 \mathrm{kN}=50000 \mathrm{~N} \\ W &=5 \mathrm{kN} \\ \text { Maximum BM } &=\frac{w^{2}}{2}+\mathrm{W} \\ &=\frac{1.5 \times 1.5^{2}}{2}+5 \times 1.50=9.1875 \mathrm{kNm} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P}{A}&=\frac{50000}{200 \times 300}=0.833 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \frac{P e}{Z}&=\frac{50000 \times 100}{200 \times \frac{300^{2}}{6}}=1.67 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \frac{M}{Z}&=\frac{9.1875 \times 10^{6}}{200 \times \frac{300^{2}}{6}}=3.0625 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}\\ \text{Stress at Q,}\qquad \qquad\\ \text { Stress at } Q &=\frac{P}{A}+\frac{P e}{Z}-\frac{M}{Z} \\ &=0.833+1.67-3.0625 \\ &=-0.56 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \text { (Tensile) } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 34 The cross-section of the reinforced concrete beam having an effective depth of 500 mm
is shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale). The grades of concrete and steel used
are M35 and Fe550, respectively. The area of tension reinforcement is 400 [latex]mm^2[/latex]. It is
given that corresponding to 0.2% proof stress, the material safety factor is 1.15 and
the yield strain of Fe550 steel is 0.0044. As per IS 456:2000, the limiting depth (in mm, round off to the nearest integer) of the
neutral axis measured from the extreme compression fiber, is ________.
solution: For a RCC T-Beam (For limiting depth of neutral axis) Considering d=500mm [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{0.0035}{x_{u,lim}}&=\frac{0.0044}{d-x_{u,lim}}\\ d-x_{u,lim}&=\frac{0.0044}{0.0035} \times x_{u,lim}\\ 35 \times 500&=35x_{u,lim}+44x_{u,lim}\\ &=79x_{u,lim}\\ x_{u,lim}&=\frac{35 \times 500}{79}\\ &=221.52 mm \end{aligned}[/latex] Limiting depth of neutral axis [latex]x_{0,lim}=221.52mm[/latex]

question:
Question 35 A concrete beam of span 15 m, 150 mm wide and 350 mm deep is prestressed with
a parabolic cable as shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale). Coefficient of friction
for the cable is 0.35, and coefficient of wave effect is 0.0015 per metre. If the cable is tensioned from one end only, the percentage loss (round off to one decimal
place) in the cable force due to friction, is ________.
solution: Jacking from one end x = L = 15 m Wobble correction factor, K = 0.0015 Coefficient of friction = 0.35 = [latex]\mu[/latex] P = Not given [latex]p_0[/latex] = Unknown Change of gradient, [latex]\alpha = \tan \alpha =\frac{8h}{L}=\frac{8 \times 120}{15000}=0.064[/latex] % loss of stress in steel due to friction [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{p_0(Kx+\mu \alpha )}{p_0} \times 100\\ &=(0.0015 \times 15+0.35 \times 0.064)\times 100 \\ &= 4.49\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

length 300 mm tested as per the split tensile strength test guidelines of IS 5816 : 1999
is 157 kN. The split tensile strength (in MPa, round off to one decimal place) of the
specimen is _______.
solution: P = 157 kN D = 150 mm L = 300 mm In split tensile strength test, split tensile strength of concrete [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{et}&=\frac{2P}{\pi DL}=\frac{2 \times 157000}{\pi \times 150 \times 300}\\ &=2.22 N/mm^2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 38 A simply supported prismatic concrete beam of rectangular cross-section, having a span
of 8 m, is prestressed with an effective prestressing force of 600 kN. The eccentricity
of the prestressing tendon is zero at supports and varies linearly to a value of e at
the mid-span. In order to balance an external concentrated load of 12 kN applied at
the mid-span, the required value of e (in mm, round off to the nearest integer) of the
tendon, is _______.
solution:
P = 600 kN Simply supported span = L = 8 m To support a point load applied at mid span (W)
= 12 kN [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Balancing load} &= \text{Point load}\\ 2P \sin \theta &=Q\\ 2P\left ( \frac{e}{L/2} \right )&=2\\ \frac{2Pe \times 2}{L}&=W\\ \frac{4Pe}{L}&=W\\ e&=\frac{WL}{4P}\\ &=\frac{12000 N \times 8000mm}{4 \times 600 \times 1000N}\\ &=40mm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 39 The singly reinforced concrete beam section shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale)
is made of M25 grade concrete and Fe500 grade reinforcing steel. The total crosssectional area of the tension steel is 942 [latex]mm^2[/latex]. As per Limit State Design of IS 456 : 2000, the design moment capacity (in kNm round
off to two decimal places) of the beam section, is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} B&=300mm\\ d&=450mm\\ A_{st}&=942 mm^2\\ M_u&=?\\ (i)\; x_{ulim}&=0.46 \times d\\ &=0.46 \times 450=207mm\\ (ii)\;\; x_u&=\frac{0.87f_yA_{st}}{0.36 f_{ck}B}\\ &=\frac{0.87 \times 500 \times 942}{0.36 \times 25 \times 300}\\ &=151.77mm\\ (iii)\;\; x_y &\lt x_{ulim}\; \text{It is under reinforcement section}\\ (iv)\;\; M_u&=0.36f_{ck}B x_u(d-0.42x_u)\\ &=0.36 \times 25 \times 300 \times 151.77 \\ &\times (450-0.42 \times 151.77)/10^6\\ &=158.28kN-m \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 42 When aspecimen of M25 concrete is loaded to a stress level of 12.5 MPa, a strain of [latex]500 \times 10^{-6}[/latex] is recorded. If this load is allowed to stand for a long time, the strain increasesto [latex]1000 \times 10^{-6}[/latex]. In accordance with the provisions of IS:456-2000, considering the long-term effects, the effective modulus of elasticity of the concrete (in MPa) is________
solution: Effective modulus of elastic [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{ce}&=\frac{E_c}{1+\theta } \\ E_c&= 5000\sqrt{f_{ck}}\\ &= 5000\sqrt{25}\\ &=25000MPa \end{aligned}[/latex] Creep coefcient [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta &=\frac{\text{creep strain}}{\text{elastic strain}} \\ &= \frac{\text{longterm strain - elastic strain}}{\text{elastic strain}}\\ &=\frac{(1000 \times 10^{-6})-(500 \times 10^{-6})}{(500 \times 10^{-6})}=1\\ \therefore \;\;E_{ce}&=\frac{25000}{1+1}=12500MPa \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 43 In the context of provisions relating to durability of concrete, consider the following assertions: Assertion (1): As per IS 456-2000, air entrainment to the extent of 3% to 6% is required for concrete exposed to marine environment. Assertion (2): The equivalent alkali content (in terms of [latex]Na_2O[/latex] equivalent) for a cement containing 1% and 0.6% of [latex]Na_2O[/latex] and [latex]K_2O[/latex], respectively, is approximately 1.4% (rounded to 1 decimal place). Which one of the following statements is CORRECT?
solution:
(1) As per clause 8.2.2.3 of IS 456-2000, entrained air percentage of 3 to 6% is required to resist freezing and thawing, i.e. not for marine environment. Hence, Assertion (1) is wrong Equivalent alkali content is terms of [latex]Na_2O[/latex] [latex]
= [Na_2 O] + 0.685 [K_2 O][/latex] [latex]
= 1 + 0.685 \times 0.6 = 1.41 \%[/latex] Hence, Assertion (2) is correct

options.A: Assertion (1) is FALSE and Assertion (2) is TRUE
options.B: Assertion (1) is TRUE and Assertion (2) is FALSE
options.C: Both Assertion (1) and Assertion (2) are FALSE
options.D: Both Assertion (1) and Assertion (2) are TRUE

question: Question 44 The characteristic compressive strength of concrete required in a project is 25MPa and the standard deviation in the observed compressive strength expected at site is 4MPa. The average compressive strength of cubes tested at different water-cement (w/c) ratios using the same material as is used for the project is given in the table. The water-cement ratio (in percent, round off to the lower integer) to be used in the mix is _____
solution: Target mean strength [latex]\begin{aligned} &=f_{ck}+1.65\sigma \\ &= 25+1.65 \times 4.0\\ &= 31.6 \end{aligned}[/latex] Water content required, [latex]=50-\frac{50-45}{35-25}\times (31.6-25)=46.7\%[/latex] say 46% (round off to the lower integer)

question: Question 45 A 3mx3m square precast reinforced concrete segments to be installed by pushing them through an existing railway embankment for making an underpass as shown in the figure. A reaction arrangement using precast PCC blocks placed on the ground is to be made for the jacks. At each stage, the jacks are required to apply a force of 1875 kN to push the segment. The jacks will react against the rigid steel plate placed against the reaction arrangement. The footprint area of reaction arrangement on natural ground is 37.5 [latex]m^2[/latex]. The unit weight of PCC block is 24 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]. The properties of the natural ground are: c = 17 kPa; [latex]\phi =25^{\circ}[/latex] and [latex]\gamma =18 kN/m^3[/latex]. Assuming that the reaction arrangement has rough interface and has the same properties that of soil, the factor of safety (round off to 1 decimal place) against shear failure is _____
solution: Weight of Precast PCC block, [latex]W=volume \times \gamma _c=37.5 \times 7.5 \times 24=6750kN[/latex] Shear resistance below the Precast PCC block is, [latex]S = C.A + W\tan \phi[/latex] F.O safety against shear failure, [latex]\begin{aligned} F&=\frac{S}{T} \\ F&=\frac{C.A.+W \tan \phi }{T} \\ &= \frac{C.A.+N \tan \phi }{T}\;\;\; (Since, \; N=W)\\ &= \frac{17 \times 37.5+6750 \times \tan 25^{\circ}}{1875}\\ &= 2.0187\approx 2.0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 Tie bars of 12 mm diameter are to be provided in a concrete pavement slab. The working tensile stress of the tie bars is 230 MPa, the average bond strength between a tie bar and concrete is 2 MPa, and the joint gap between the slabs is 10 mm. Ignoring the loss of bond and the tolerance factor, the design length of the tie bars (in mm, round off to the nearest integer) is _____
solution: [latex]L_d=\frac{\phi \sigma _{st}}{4\tau _{bd}}=\frac{12 \times 230}{4 \times 2}=345mm[/latex] Length of tie bar [latex]=L_d+10+L_d=345+10+345=700mm[/latex]

question: Question 47 For a given loading on a rectangular plain concrete beam with an overall depth of 500 mm, the compressive strain and tensile strain developed at the extreme fibers are of the same magnitude of [latex]2.5 \times 10^{-4}[/latex]. The curvature in the beam cross-section (in [latex]m^{-1}[/latex], round off to 3 decimal places), is ____
solution: Simple bending equation [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{m}{I}&=\frac{f}{y}=\frac{E}{R} \\ \frac{1}{R}&=\frac{f}{E}\cdot \frac{1}{y} \\ &=\frac{\varepsilon }{y}=\frac{2.5 \times 10^{-4}}{(0.5/2)}=0.001m^{-1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 48 In the reinforced beam section shown in the figure, the nominal cover provided at the bottom of the beam as per IS 456-2000, is
solution: Nominal cover = Effective cover [latex]-\frac{\phi _m}{2}-\phi _{st}[/latex] [latex]=50-\frac{16}{2}-12=30mm[/latex] Nominal cover is the distance from extreme concrete fbre to the surface of stirrup.

question: Question 49 A 6 m long simply-supported beam is prestressed as shown in the figure. The beam carries a uniformly distributed load of 6 kN/m over its entire span. If the effective flexural rigidity [latex]EI=2\times 10^{4}kN/m^{2}[/latex] and the effective prestressing force is 200 kN, the net increase in length of the prestressing cable (in mm, up to two decimal places) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Span of PSC beam }&=6 \mathrm{m} \\ E I&=2 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{kNm}^{2} \\ &=2 \times 10^{13} \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ P&=200 \mathrm{kN} \\ \text { Total UDL }&=6 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \\ \text { eccentricity }&=e=50 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] (a) Slope of beam due to P-force [latex]\theta_{1}=\frac{P \cdot e \cdot L}{2 E I}[/latex] [latex]\begin{array}{l} =\frac{200 \times 10^{3} \times 50 \times 6000}{2 \times 2 \times 10^{13}} \\ =1.5 \times 10^{-3} \text {(upward) } \end{array}[/latex] (b) Slope of beam due to UDL [latex] \theta_{2}=\frac{w^{3}}{24 E I}[/latex] [latex]\begin{array}{l} =\frac{6 \times(6000)^{3}}{24 \times 2 \times 10^{13}} \\ =(+) 2.7 \times 10^{-3} \text {(downward) } \end{array}[/latex] (c) Net slope of beam [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta &=\theta_{1}+\theta_{2} \\ &=(-) 1.5 \times 10^{-3}+(+) 2.7 \times 10^{-3} \\ &=1.2 \times 10^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total net increase in length [latex] \begin{aligned} &=2 e \theta \\ &=2 \times 50 \times 1.2 \times 10^{-3} \\ &=0.12 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 A singly-reinforced rectangular concrete beam of width 300 mm and effective depth 400 mm is to be designed using M25 grade concrete and Fe500 grade reinforcing steel. For the beam to be under-reinforced, the maximum number of 16 mm diameter reinforcing bars that can be provided is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} B&=300 \mathrm{mm}\\ d&=400 \mathrm{mm} \text{ (effective depth)} \\ &\mathrm{M} 25\text{ and }\mathrm{Fe} 500 \\ A_{s t,} \lim &=0.414\left(\frac{f_{c k}}{f_{y}}\right) x_{u, l \operatorname{irn}} b \\ &=0.414\left(\frac{25}{500}\right) 0.46 \times 400 \times 300 \\ &=1142.64 \mathrm{mm}^{2}\\ \text{Number of }&16 \mathrm{mm} \phi \\ &=\frac{1142.64}{\frac{\pi}{4}(16)^{2}}=5.68\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] For [latex] A_{s t} \lt A_{s t \text { lim' }},[/latex] maximum number of bars to be provided is 5.

question: Question 51 A reinforced-concrete slab with effective depth of 80 mm is simply supported at two opposite ends on 230 mm thick masonry walls. The centre-to-centre distance between the walls is 3.3 m. As per IS 456 : 2000, the effective span of the slab (in m, up to two decimal places) is ______
solution: Effective depth [latex] d=80 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Width of support =230 mm c/c distance between walls =3.30 m Clear span of slab =3.30-0.23=3.07 m Effective span = Minimum [latex]\left\{\begin{array}{l}\left(L_{\text {clear }}+d\right) \\ c / c \text { distance between supports }\end{array}\right. [/latex] = Minimum [latex]\left\{\begin{array}{l}(3.07+0.08=3.15 \mathrm{m}) \\ 3.3 \mathrm{m}\end{array}\right. [/latex] [latex] So, \quad L_{\mathrm{eft}}=3.15 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 52 As per IS 456 : 2000, the minimum percentage of tension reinforcement (up to two decimal places) required in reinforced-concrete beams of rectangular cross-section (considering effective depth in the calculation of area) using Fe500 grade steel is ______
solution: Minimum percentage of steel (for Fe 500 ) [latex] =\frac{85}{f_{y}} \%=\frac{85}{500} \%=0.17 \%[/latex]

question: Question 53 A structural member subjected to compression, has both translation and rotation restrained at one end, while only translation is restrained at the other end. As per IS 456 : 2000, the effective length factor recommended for design is
solution: One end is fixed Other end is pin jointed Effective length of column (as per IS:456-2000)[latex]=0.08L[/latex]

question: Question 54 An RCC beam of rectangular cross section has factored shear of 200 kN at its critical section. Its width b is 250 mm and effective depth d is 350 mm. Assume design shear strength [latex]\tau _{c}[/latex] of concrete as 0.62 [latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex] and maximum allowable shear stress [latex]\tau _{c,max}[/latex]    in concrete as 2.8 [latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex] . If two legged 10 mm diameter vertical stirrups of Fe250 grade steel are used, then the required spacing (in cm, up to one decimal place) as per limit state method will be ______
solution: Nominal shear stress, [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau_{v}&=\frac{V_{u}}{b d}=\frac{200 \times 10^{3}}{250 \times 350}=2.286 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \lt \tau_{c m a x} \\ &\text{(OK)}\\ SF&\text{ taken by stirrups}\\ &=\left(\tau_{v}-\tau_{c}\right) b d \\ &=(2.286-0.62) \times 250 \times 350 \\ &=145.75 \mathrm{kN} \\ \text{Now, }V_{u s}&=\frac{0.87 f_{y} A_{s v} d}{S_{v}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad S_{v}&=\frac{0.87 \times 250 \times 350 \times 2 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times 10^{2}}{145.75 \times 10^{3}} \\ &=82 \mathrm{mm}=8.2 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 An RCC short column (with lateral ties) of rectangular cross section of 250 mm x 300 mm is reinforced with four numbers of 16 mm diameter longitudinal bars. The grades of steel and concrete are Fe415 and M20, respectively. Neglect eccentricity effect. Considering limit state of collapse in compression (IS 456 : 2000), the axial load carrying capacity of the column (in kN, up to one decimal place), is ______
solution: since eccentricity effect is being neglected so column can be considered as concentrically loaded. Ultimate axial load carrying capacity of column. [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{u} &=0.45 \mathrm{f}_{c k} A_{g}+\left(0.75 \mathrm{f}_{y}-0.45 \mathrm{f}_{c k}\right) A_{\mathrm{sc}} \\ &=0.45 \times 20 \times 250 \times 300 \\ &+(0.75 \times 415-0.45 \times 20) 4 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times 16^{2} \\ &=918.1 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 The frequency distribution of the compressive strength of 20 concrete cube specimens is given in the table. If [latex]\mu [/latex] is the mean strength of the specimens and [latex]\sigma[/latex] is the standard deviation, the number of specimens (out of 20) with compressive strength less than [latex]\mu -3\sigma[/latex] is ______
solution: Average strength, [latex] \begin{aligned} \mu &=\frac{(4 \times 23)+(2 \times 28)+(5 \times 22.5)+(5 \times 31)+(4 \times 29)}{20} \\ &=26.575 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \sigma &=\sqrt{\frac{\Sigma(\mu-f)^{2}}{n-1}} \\ &=\sqrt{\frac{\begin{array}{c} (26.575-23)^{2} \times 4+(26.575-28)^{2} \times 2\\ +(26.575-22.5)^{2} \times 5+(26.575-31)^{2} \\ \times 5+(26.575-29)^{2} \times 4 \end{array}}{(20-1)}} \\&=3.7 \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, [latex]\mu-3 \sigma=26.575-3 \times 3.7=15.48 [/latex] Thus, no specimen is having compressive strength less than [latex]\mu-3 \sigma.[/latex]

question: Question 57 Two rectangular under-reinforced concrete beam sections X and Y are similar in all aspects except that the longitudinal compression reinforcement in section Y is 10% more. Which one of the following is the correct statement?
solution:
Due to presence of more compression steel in 
section Y, NA of section of Y is above than as 
of X. It means Y is more under-reinforced than 
X so ductility of Y is more. Since compression steel of Y is more so flexure 
resistance of X is less than as of Y.

options.A: Section X has less flexural strength and is less ductile than section Y
options.B: Section X has less flexural strength but is more ductile than section Y
options.C: Sections X and Y have equal flexural strength but different ductility
options.D: Sections X and Y have equal flexural strength and ductility

question: Question 58 The deformation in concrete due to sustained loading is
solution:
Creep is inelastic deformation with time due to
sustained loading

question: Question 59 A column of height h with a rectangular cross-section of size ax2a has a buckling load of P. If the cross-section is changed to 0.5a x 3a and its height changed to 1.5h, the buckling load of the redesigned column will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { For column, } & P=\frac{\pi^{2} E I_{\min }}{L^{2}} \\ &=\frac{\pi^{2} E\left(\frac{2 a \times a^{3}}{12}\right)}{h^{2}}=\frac{\pi^{2} E a^{4}}{6 h^{2}}\\ \text{For new column, }P&=\frac{\pi^{2} E\left[\frac{3 a \times(0.5 a)^{3}}{12}\right]}{(1.5 h)^{2}} \\ &=\frac{1}{12} \times \frac{\pi^{2} E a^{4}}{6 h^{2}}=\frac{P}{12} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 60 A simply supported rectangular concrete beam of span 8m has to be prestressed with a force of 1600 kN. The tendon is of parabolic profile having zero eccentricity at the supports. The beam has to carry an external uniformly distributed load of intensity 30 kN/m. Neglecting the self-weight of the beam, the maximum dip (in meters, up to two decimal places) of the tendon at the mid-span to balance the external load should be_______
solution: [latex]\text { Central dip, } e=\frac{w^{2}}{8 P}=\frac{30 \times 8^{2}}{8 \times 1600}=0.15 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 61 Let the characteristic strength be defined as that value, below which not more than 50% of the results are expected to fall. Assuming a standard deviation of 4 MPa, the target mean strength (in MPa) to be considered in the mix design of a M25 concrete would be
solution: If [latex]f_{c k}[/latex] is the value below which not more than 50% of test results are expected then, [latex] f_{m}=f_{c k}[/latex] [Mean strength = Characteristics strength] So target mean strength of concrete to be considered in design mix. = Mean strength [latex] =f_{m}=f_{c k}=25 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex]

question: Question 62 A pre-tensioned rectangular concrete beam 150 mm wide and 300 mm depth is prestressed with three straight tendons, each having a cross-sectional area of 50 [latex]mm^{2}[/latex], to an initial stress of 1200 [latex]N / mm^{2}[/latex]. The tendons are located at 100 mm from the soffit of the beam. If the modular ratio is 6, the loss of prestressing force (in kN, up to one decimal place) due to the elastic deformation of concrete only is ______
solution: Prestressing force, [latex] \begin{aligned} P&=3 \times 50 \times 1200=180000 \mathrm{N} \\ e&=\left(\frac{D}{2}-100\right)=\left(\frac{300}{2}-100\right)=50 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Stress in concrete at the location of steel [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{P}{A}+\frac{P \cdot e}{I} e\\ &=\frac{180000}{150 \times 300}+\frac{180000 \times 50^{2}}{\left(\frac{150 \times 300^{3}}{12}\right)} \\ &=4.0+1.33=5.333 \end{aligned}[/latex] Loss of stress [latex] =m \times f_{c}=6 \times 5.3333=32 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex] Loss of prestressing force [latex] =\frac{3 \times 50 \times 32}{1000} \mathrm{kN}=4.8 \mathrm{kN}[/latex]

question: Question 63 According to IS 456-2000, which one of the following statements about the depth of neutral axis [latex]\chi _{u,bal}[/latex]  for a balanced reinforced concrete section is correct?
solution: [latex]x_{u, \text { bal }}=\frac{700}{1100+0.87 f_{y}} \times d[/latex] So it depends upon grade of steel only.

options.A: [latex]\chi _{u,bal}[/latex]  depends on the grade of concrete only.
options.B: [latex]\chi _{u,bal}[/latex]  depends on the grade of steel only.
options.C: [latex]\chi _{u,bal}[/latex]  depends on both the grade of concrete and grade of steel.
options.D: [latex]\chi _{u,bal}[/latex]  bal does not depend on the grade of concrete and grade of steel.

question: Question 64 A haunched (varying depth) reinforced concrete beam is simply supported at both ends, as shown in the figure. The beam is subjected to a uniformly distributed factored load of intensity 10 kN/m. The design shear force (expressed in kN) at the section X-X of the beam is ___________.
solution: Shear force at section X-X. [latex] V_{u}=100-5 \times 10=50 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] Depth at section X-X [latex] d=400+\frac{200}{10} \times 5=500 \mathrm{mm}=0.5 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Moment at section X-X, [latex] M_{u}=100 \times 5-10 \times 2.5 \times 5=375 \mathrm{kNm}[/latex] Design shear force at section X-X [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{\text {udesign }}&=V_{u}+\frac{M_{u}}{d} \tan \beta \\ &=50+\frac{375}{0.5} \times \frac{200}{10000}=65 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 As per IS 456-2000 for the design of reinforced concrete beam, the maximum allowable shear stress [latex]\tau _{cmax}[/latex]  depends on the

options.A: grade of concrete and grade of steel
options.D: grade of concrete and percentage of reinforcement

question: Question 66 For M25 concrete with creep coefficient of 1.5, the long-term static modulus of elasticity (expressed in MPa) as per the provisions of IS:456-2000 is __________.
solution: Long term static modulus of elasticity, [latex] \begin{aligned} E_{\theta} &=\frac{E_{C}}{1+\theta}=\frac{5000 \sqrt{f_{c k}}}{1+\theta}=\frac{5000 \sqrt{25}}{1+1.5} \\ &=10,000 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 67 A reinforced concrete (RC) beam with width of 250 mm and effective depth of 400 mm is reinforced with Fe415 steel. As per the provisions of IS 456-2000, the minimum and maximum amount of tensile reinforcement (expressed in [latex]mm^{2}[/latex] ) for the section are, respectively
solution: Minimum tension reinforcement is given by, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{A_{s}}{b d} &=\frac{0.85}{f_{y}} \\ A_{s} &=\frac{0.85 \times 250 \times 400}{415}=205 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum compression reinforcement =0.04bD [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.04 \times 250 \times 400 \\ &=4000 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 In shear design of an RC beam, other than the allowable shear strength of concrete [latex](\tau _{c})[/latex] there is also an additional check suggested in IS 456-2000 with respect to the maximum permissible shear stress [latex](\tau _{cmax})[/latex]. The check for [latex](\tau _{cmax})[/latex] is required to take care of

options.A: additional shear resistance from reinforcing steel
options.B: additional shear stress that comes from accidental loading
options.C: possibility of failure of concrete by diagonal tension
options.D: possibility of crushing of concrete by diagonal compression

question: Question 69 In a pre-stressed concrete beam section shown in the figure, the net loss is 10% and the final pre-stressing force applied at X is 750 kN. The initial fiber stresses (in [latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex] ) at the top and bottom of the beam were:
solution:
Given, net loss =10 % Final prestressing force after loss =750 kN Hence, initial prestressing force [latex]
=\frac{750}{0.9}=833.33 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] Initial stresses at top and bottom [latex]
\begin{array}{l} 
=\frac{P}{A} \pm \frac{P e}{Z}=\frac{833.33 \times 10^{3}}{250 \times 400} \pm \frac{833.33 \times 10^{3} \times 100 \times 6}{250 \times 400^{2}} \\
=8.33 \pm 12.50 \\
\end{array}[/latex] Stress at top [latex]=8.33-12.50=-4.17[/latex] (tensile) Stress at bottom [latex]=8.33+12.50=20.83[/latex] (Comp.)

question: Question 70 According to the concept of Limit State Design as per IS 456: 2000, the probability of failure of a structure is__________.
solution: The structure may fail when, the load exceeds the design load (ii) the strength is less than the characteristic strength (iii) both the load exceeds the design load and strength is less than the characteristic strength. The probability of load exceeding design load = 5% (iv) The probability of strength less than characteristic strength = 5% The probability of failure is [latex] =0.05 \times 0.95+0.05 \times 0.95+0.05 \times 0.05 [/latex] [latex] =0.0975[/latex]

question: Question 71 A column of size 450 mm x 600 mm has unsupported length of 3.0 m and is braced against side sway in both directions. According to IS 456:2000, the minimum eccentricities (in mm) with respect to major and minor principle axes are:
solution: [latex]e_{\min }=\operatorname{maximum}\left\{\begin{array}{l} \frac{L}{500}+\frac{D}{30} \\ 20 \mathrm{mm} \end{array}\right.[/latex] x-x will be major axis and y-y will be minor axis. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad e_{\min y y}&=\frac{3000}{500}+\frac{450}{30}=21 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text{and }\quad e_{\min xx}&=\frac{3000}{500}+\frac{600}{30}=26 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 72 Consider the singly reinforced beam section given below (left figure). The stress block parameters for the cross-section from IS: 456 : 2000 are also given below (right figure). The moment of resistance for the given section by the limit state method is ________ kN-m
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A_{s t} &=4 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times 12^{2} \\ &=452.38 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ x_{u, \lim } &=0.48 \times 300=144 \mathrm{mm} \\ \because \quad C &=T \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.36 f_{c k} b x_{u} &=0.87 \mathrm{f}_{y} A_{s t} \\ \Rightarrow \quad x_{u}&=\frac{0.87 f_{y} A_{s t}}{0.36 f_{c k} b}=90.73 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \because x_{u} \lt x_{u, l \mathrm{im}},[/latex] it is under reinforced section [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad M O R&=0.36 f_{c k} b x_{u}\left(d-0.42 x_{u}\right) \\ &=42.7708 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{mm} \\ &=42.7708 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 The composition of an air-entrained concrete is given below: Assume the specific gravity of OPC, sand and coarse aggregate top be 3.14, 2.67 and 2.74, respectively. The air content is ________ [latex]litres/m^{3}[/latex] .
solution: Let the total volume of air-entrained concrete is unity. [latex] \begin{array}{c} \frac{M_{C}}{\rho_{C}}+\frac{M_{F A}}{\rho_{F A}}+\frac{M_{C A}}{\rho_{C A}}+V_{W}+V_{\mathrm{Air}}=1.0 \\ \frac{368}{3.14 \times 1000}+\frac{606}{2.67 \times 1000} \\ +\frac{1155}{2.74 \times 1000}+\frac{184}{1000}+V_{V}=1.0 \\ 0.11720+0.22697+0.42153 \\ \begin{aligned} +0.184+V_{v}&=1.0 \\ V_{V}&=0.0503 \\ V_{V}&=0.0503 \times 1000 \\ \quad&=50.3\; litres / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 74 The development length of a deformed reinforncement bar can be expressed as (1/k) [latex](\phi \sigma _{s}/\tau _{bd})[/latex]. From the IS: 456-2000, the value of k can be calculated as________.
solution: Bond strength of concrete [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\text{ Tensile force in steel}\\ \tau_{b d} \times\left(L_{d} \pi \phi\right)&=0.87 f_{y} \times\left(\frac{\pi}{4} \phi^{2}\right)\\ \Rightarrow \quad L_{d}&=\frac{0.87 f_{y} \phi}{4 \tau_{b d}} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] For deformed bars [latex]\tau_{\text {bd }}[/latex] value is increased by 60 % [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad L_{d}&=\frac{\phi \sigma_{s}}{4 \times\left(1.6 \tau_{b d}\right)}=\frac{\phi \sigma_{s}}{6.4 \tau_{b d}}\\ \therefore \quad k&=6.4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 75 Consider the singly reinforced beam shown in the figure below: At cross-section XX, which of the following statements is TRUE at the limit state?

options.A: The variation of stress is linear and that of strain is non-linear
options.B: The variation of strain is linear and that of stress is non-linear
options.C: The variation of both stress and strain is linear
options.D: The variation of both stress and strain is non- linear

question: Question 76 Consider the following statements for air-entrained concrete. (i) Air-entrainment reduces the water demand for a given level of workability (ii) Use of air-entrained concrete is required in environments where cyclic freezing and thawing is expected Which of the following is TRUE?
solution:
An air-entraining agent introduces air in the form 
of bubbles that occupy upto 5% of the volume of 
concrete distributed uniformly throughout cement 
paste. Thus, for the same amount of water/cement 
ratio, we get higher workability.

question: Question 77 Workability of concrete can be measured using slump, compaction factor and Vebe time. Consider the following statements for workability of concrete: (i) As the slump increases, the Vebe time increases (ii) As the slump increases, the compaction factor increases Which of the following is TRUE?
solution:
As slump increase, water content increases means 
workability increases. Compaction factor [latex]
 =\frac{\text { Weight of partially compacted concrete }}{\text { Weight of fully compacted concrete }} [/latex] [latex]
 \therefore [/latex] Compaction factor will also increase. The time required for complete remoulding in 
seconds is considered as a measure of 
workability and is expressed as the number of 
Vee-Bee seconds. [latex]
\therefore [/latex] As workability increases, Vee-Bee time decreases.

question: Question 78 The modulus of elasticity, [latex]E=5000\sqrt{f_{ck}}[/latex]  where [latex]f_{ck}[/latex] is the characteristic compressive strength of concrete, specified in IS:456-2000 is based on
solution: In IS:456-2000, the modulus of elasticity of concrete is given by: [latex] E = 5000 \sqrt{f_{ck}} \quad \text{(in MPa)} [/latex] This value is derived from the stress-strain curve of concrete and is defined as the secant modulus, which is the slope of the line joining the origin to a point on the stress-strain curve at working stress level (typically at 0.33 of ultimate strength).

question: Question 79 The flexural tensile strength of M25 grade of concrete, in [latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex], as per IS:456-2000 is
solution: [latex]\text { Flexural strength }=0.7 \sqrt{f_{c k}}=3.5 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 80 The target means strength [latex]f_{cm}[/latex] for concrete mix design obtained from the characteristic strength [latex]f_{ck}[/latex] and standard deviation [latex]\sigma[/latex], as defined in IS:456-2000, is

Question 83 In a reinforced concrete section, the stress at the extreme fibre in compression is 5.80 MPa. The depth of neutral axis in the section is 58 mm and the grade of concrete is M25. Assuming linear elastic behavior of the concrete, the effective curvature of the section (in per mm) is
solution: Modulus of elasticity of concrete. [latex] \begin{aligned} E &=5000 \sqrt{25} \\ &=25000 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{M}{I} &=\frac{\sigma}{y}=\frac{E}{R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{R} &=\frac{\sigma}{E y}=\frac{5.8}{E X_{u}} \\ \text { Curvature } &=\frac{5.8}{58 \times 25000} \\ &=4 \times 10^{-6} \text {Per } \mathrm{mm} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \text { Curvature }&=4 \times 10^{-6} \text {per } \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 84 For a beam of cross -section, width = 230 mm and effective depth = 500 mm, the number of rebars of 12 mm diameter required to satisfy minimum tension reinforcement requirement specified by IS:456-2000 (assuming grade of steel reinforcement as Fe500) is _____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{A_{\text {stmin }}}{b d} &=\frac{0.85}{f_{y}} \\ \text{or},\quad \quad A_{s t} &=\frac{0.85}{500} \times 230 \times 500 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ n &=\frac{A_{s t}}{\frac{\pi d^{2}}{4}}=\frac{0.85 \times 230}{\frac{\pi}{4}(12)^{2}} \\ &=1.729=2 \mathrm{bars} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 A rectangular beam of width (b) 230 mm and effective depth (d) 450 mm is reinforced with four bars of 12 mm diameter. The grade of concrete is M20 and grade of steel is Fe500. Given that for M20 grade of concrete the ultimate shear strength, [latex]\tau _{uc} = 0.36 N/mm^{2}[/latex] for steel percentage, p = 0.25, and [latex]\tau _{uc}= 0.48 N/mm^{2}[/latex] for p = 0.50. For a factored shear force of 45 kN, the diameter (in mm) of Fe500 steel two legged stirrups to be used at spacing of 375 mm, should be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau_{u c}=& 0.36 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} &[\text{For M20}]\\ & \text { for } \frac{A_{s t}}{b d} \times 100=0.25\\ \tau_{u c}=& 0.48 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} &[\text{For M20}]\\ & \text { for } \frac{A_{s t}}{b d} \times 100=0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] Factored [latex]S F=45 \mathrm{kN}=V_{u} [/latex] We have to calculate the dia of Fe 500 2-Legged stirrup to be used at a spacing of 325 mm c/c [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau_{v}&=\frac{V_{u}}{b d}=\frac{45 \times 1000}{230 \times 450}=0.4348 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}\\ \therefore \quad \%&\text{tensile steel}\\ &=\frac{4 \times \frac{\pi}{4}(12)^{2}}{230 \times 450} \times 100=0.437 \% \\ \tau_{c} &=0.36+\frac{0.12}{0.25} \times(0.437-0.25) \\ &=0.45 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] since [latex]\tau_{v}-\tau_{c} \lt 0 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] Min shear reinforcement is required [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] Min shear reinforcement is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{A_{s v}}{b S_{v}} &=\frac{0.4}{0.87 f_{y}} \\ A_{s v} &=\frac{0.4 \times\left(S_{v}\right)(b)}{0.87 f_{y}} \end{aligned}[/latex] since we limit [latex]f_{y}[/latex] to [latex]415 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex] hence, [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{s v}=2 \times \frac{\pi}{4}(\phi)^{2} &=\frac{0.4 \times 325 \times 230}{0.87 \times 415} \\ &= 82.814 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \phi &=7.26 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { adopt } \phi&=8 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 86 While designing, for a steel column of Fe250 grade, a base plate resting on a concrete pedestal of M20 grade, the bearing strength of concrete (in [latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex]) in limit state method of design as per IS:456-2000 is ________________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text { Permissible bearing stress } \\ &=0.45 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{ck}} \\ &=0.45 \times 20=9 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 Match the information given in Group - I with those in Group - II.

Question 88 A rectangular concrete beam 250mm wide and 600mm deep is pre-stressed by means of 16 high
tensile wires, each of 7 mm diameter, located at 200mm from the bottom face of the beam at a
given section. If the effective pre-stress in the wires is 700MPa, what is the maximum sagging
bending moment (in kNm) (correct to 1-decimal place) due to live load that this section of the beam
can with stand without causing tensile stress at the bottom face of the beam? Neglect the effect of dead load of beam.
solution: since the tensile stress at bottom face of the beam is zero. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{P}{A}+\frac{P e}{I} y-\frac{M}{I} y &=0 \\ P &=700 \times \frac{\pi}{4}(7)^{2} \times 16 \\ &=431.026 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex] since the prestressing force is located at 200 mm from the bottom face of the beam. [latex]\therefore[/latex] Eccentricity [latex]=300-200=100 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{431.03 \times 10^{3}}{250 \times 600}+\frac{431.03 \times 10^{3} \times 100}{250 \times 600^{2}} \times 6 \\ =\frac{M \times 6}{250 \times 600^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow 2.87+2.87=6.66 \times 10^{-8} M \\ \Rightarrow M=86.205 \mathrm{kNm} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 89 As per IS 456:2000 for M20 grade concrete and plain barsin tension the design bond stress [latex]\tau _{bd}=1.2 MPa[/latex].Further, IS 456:2000 permits this design bond stress value to be increased by 60% for HSD bars. The stress in the HSD reinforcing steel barsin tension, [latex]\sigma _{s}=360MPa[/latex]. Find the required development length, [latex]L_{d}[/latex], for HSD barsin terms of the bar diameter, [latex]\phi[/latex]. __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{d} &=\frac{\phi \sigma_{s t}}{4 \tau_{b d}}=\frac{\phi \times 360}{4 \times 1.2 \times 1.60} \\ &=46.875 \phi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 90 Maximum possible value of Compacting Factor for fresh (green) concrete is:

Question 91 The cross-section at mid-span of a beam at the edge of
a slab is shown in the sketch. A portion of the slab is
considered as the effective flange width for the beam.
The grades of concrete and reinforcing steel are M25
and Fe415, respectively. The total area of reinforcing
bars ([latex]A_s[/latex]) is 4000 [latex]mm^2[/latex]. At the ultimate limit state, [latex]x_u[/latex]
denotes the depth of the neutral axis from the top
fibre. Treat the section as under-reinforced and
flanged ([latex]x_u \gt [/latex]100 mm). The ultimate moment capacity (in kNm) of the section, as per the Limit State Method of
IS 456:2000 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} M_{u}=& 0.36 f_{c k}(325) X_{u} \\ &\left(d-0.42 X_{u}\right)+0.45\\ \text{or}\quad \quad &f_{ck} (675) 100(d-50) \\ &=0.36 \times 25 \times 325 \times 236.3 \\ &\quad(570-0.42 \times 236.3)+0.45 \\ &\quad \times 25 \times 675 \times 100(570-50) \\ &=325.374+394.875 \\ &=720.25 \mathrm{kNm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Take [latex]717.00 \mathrm{kNm}[/latex]

question:
Question 92 The cross-section at mid-span of a beam at the edge of
a slab is shown in the sketch. A portion of the slab is
considered as the effective flange width for the beam.
The grades of concrete and reinforcing steel are M25
and Fe415, respectively. The total area of reinforcing
bars ([latex]A_s[/latex]) is 4000 [latex]mm^2[/latex]. At the ultimate limit state, [latex]x_u[/latex]
denotes the depth of the neutral axis from the top
fibre. Treat the section as under-reinforced and
flanged ([latex]x_u \gt [/latex]100 mm). The value of [latex]x_u[/latex] (in mm) computed as per the Limit State Method of IS 456:2000 is
solution: [latex]\mathrm{Given}, X_{u} \gt 100 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] and section is under reinforced. [latex] \begin{array}{c} \Rightarrow 0.36 f_{c k}(325) X_{u}+0.45 f_{c k}(675) \times 100 \\ =0.87 f_{y} A_{s t}\\ \Rightarrow 0.36 \times 25 \times 325 X_{u}+0.45 \times 25 \times 625 \times 100 \\ \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.87 \times 415 \times 4000 \\ \Rightarrow \quad X_{u}&=234.13 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text{Take }\quad X_{u}&=236.3 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text{Check }\quad x_{u (I)}&=0.48 \times 570 \\ &=273.6 \\ \therefore \quad X_{u}& \lt X_{u(I)} &\text{(OK)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 93 A concrete beam prestressed with a parabolic tendon is shown in the sketch. The eccentricity of the
tendon is measured from the centroid of the cross-section. The applied prestressing force at service
is 1620 kN. The uniformly distributed load of 45 kN/m includes the self-weight. The stress (in N/[latex]mm^2[/latex]) in the bottom fibre at mid-span is
solution: [latex]\text { Total stress at Bottom }=\frac{P}{A}+\frac{P_{\theta}}{I} y-\frac{M}{Z}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Here, } Z &=\frac{b d^{2}}{6}=\frac{500 \times 750^{2}}{6} \\ &=46.875 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ e &=145 \mathrm{mm} ; P=1620 \mathrm{kN} \\ M &=\frac{w l^{2}}{8}=\frac{45 \times 7.3^{2}}{8}=299.76 \mathrm{kNm} \\ \therefore \frac{P}{A} &=\frac{1620 \times 10^{3}}{500 \times 750}=4.32 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \frac{P e}{Z} &=\frac{1620 \times 10^{3} \times 145}{46.875 \times 10^{6}}=5.01 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \frac{M}{Z}&=\frac{299.76 \times 10^{6}}{46.875 \times 10^{6}} =6.39 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \therefore &\text { Total stress at bottom } =4.32+5.01-6.39 \\ &=2.94 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} . \text { (comp.) } \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 96 Consider two RCC beams, P and Q, each having the section 400 mm x 750 mm
(effective depth, d = 750 mm) made with concrete having a [latex]\tau _{cmax}=2.1N/mm^{2}[/latex]. For the reinforcement provided and the grade of concrete used, it may be assumed that the [latex]\tau _{c}=0.75N/mm^{2}[/latex]. The design shear in beam P is 400 kN and in beam Q is 750 kN. Considering the provisions of IS 456-2000, which of the following statements is TRUE?
solution:
Shear strength of the concrete [latex] =\tau_{c} \times B d [/latex] [latex]
=0.75 \times 400 \times 750 \times 10^{-3}=225 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] Maximum shear strength of concrete [latex]
\begin{array}{l}
=\tau_{c \max } \times B d \\
=2.1 \times 400 \times 750 \times 10^{-3}=630 \mathrm{kN}
\end{array}[/latex] Design shear in beam P is 400kN which is less 
than the maximum shear that the concrete can 
sustain. But the design shear is more than the 
nominal shear of 225 kN. [latex]
 \therefore [/latex] Shear reinforcement is designed for [latex]
=400-225=175 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] Design shear in beam Q is 750 kN which is more 
than the maximum shear that the concrete can 
sustain. Hence the beam Q should be redesigned.

options.A:
Shere reinforcement should be designed for 175 kN for beam P and the
section for beam Q should be revised.
options.B:
Nominal shear reinforcement is required for beam P and the shear
reinforcement should be designed for 120 kN for beam Q.
options.C:
Shear reinforcement should be designed for 175 kN for beam P and the
shear reinforcement should be designed for 525 kN for beam Q.
options.D: The sections for both beams P and Q need to be revised.

Question 97 Consider a bar of diameter 'D' embedded in a large concrete block as shown in
the adjoining figure, with a pull out force P being applied. Let [latex]\sigma _b[/latex] and [latex]\sigma _{st}[/latex] be the
bond strength (between the bar and concrete) and the tensile strength of the bar,
respectively. If the block is held in position and it is assumed that the material
of the block does not fail, which of the following options represents the maximum
value of P?
solution: Maximum force resisted by bond strength [latex] =\sigma_{b}(\pi D L) [/latex] Maximum tensile force resisted by bar [latex] =\sigma_{s t}\left(\frac{\pi}{4} D^{2}\right) [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Maximum value of P= Minimum of [latex] \left\{\sigma_{b}(\pi D L)\text{or}\left(\sigma_{s t} \frac{\pi}{4} D^{2}\right)\right\}[/latex]

question:
Question 99 Consider a reinforcing bar embedded in concrete. In a marine environment this bar
undergoes uniform corrosion, which leads to the deposition of corrosion products
on its surface and an increase in the apparent volume of the bar. This subjects the
surrounding concrete to expansive pressure. As a result, corrosion induced cracks
appear at the surface of concrete. Which of the following statements is TRUE?
solution:
Corrosion in steel occupies a volume several times
greater than volume of reinforcing steel hence
exerts radial pressure on adjoining concrete layer.
As a consequence, cracking results along
reinforcing bars and concrete starts spalling.

options.A:
Corrosion causes circumferential tensile stresses in concrete and the cracks
will be parallel to the corroded reinforcing bar.
options.B:
Corrosion causes radial tensile stresses in concrete and the cracks will be
parallel to the corroded reinforcng bar.
options.C:
Corrosion causes circumferential tensile stresses in concrete and the cracks
will be perpendicular to the direction of the corroded reinforcing bar.
options.D:
Corrosion causes radial tensile stresses in concrete and the cracks will be
perpendicular to the direction of the corroded reinforcing bar.

Question 100 A 16 mm thick plate measuring 650 mm x 420 mm is used as a base plate for an
ISHB 300 column subjected to a factored axial compressive load of 2000 kN. As
per IS 456-2000, the minimum grade of concrete that should be used below the
base plate for safely carrying the load is
solution:
Working axial load [latex]
\begin{aligned}
&=\frac{\text { Factored axial load }}{1.5} \\
&=\frac{2000}{1.5}=1333.33 \mathrm{kN}
\end{aligned}[/latex] The allowable bearing pressure on concrete may be given as, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{\text {all }} &=\frac{\text { Direct load }}{\text { Area of base plate }} \\
&=\frac{1333.33 \times 10^{3}}{650 \times 420}=4.88 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}
\end{aligned}[/latex] The permissible stress in direct compression in 
various grades of concrete as per IS 456: 2000 
are tabulated below: The permissible stress in concrete should be more 
than the allowable bearing pressure. Thus the 
minimum grade of concrete which should be used 
is M20

question:
Question 101 A doubly reinforced rectangular concrete beam has a width of 300mm and an effective
depth of 500mm. the beam is reinforced with 2200[latex]mm^2[/latex] of steel in tension and 628[latex]mm^2[/latex]
of steel in compression. The effective cover for compression steel is 50mm. Assume that
both tension and compression steel yield. The grades of concrete and steel used are M20
and Fe250 respectively. The stress lock parameters (rounded off to first two decimal
places) for concrete shall be as per IS 456:200. The moment of resistance of the section is
solution: Moment of resistance [latex]M_{u}[/latex] is given by. [latex] \begin{aligned} M_{u}=& C_{u c}\left(d-0.42 x_{u}\right)+C_{u s}(d-d) \\ =& 0.36 f_{c k} b r_{u}\left(d-0.42 x_{U}\right) \\ &+\left(f_{s c}-0.45 f_{c k}\right) A_{s c}(d-d) \\ =& 0.36 \times 20 \times 300 \times 160.91 \\ &(500-0.42 \times 160.91) \\ &+(0.87 \times 250-0.45 \times 20) \\ & \times 628(500-50) \\ =& 209215652.1 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m} \\ =& 209.21 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 102 A doubly reinforced rectangular concrete beam has a width of 300mm and an effective
depth of 500mm. the beam is reinforced with 2200[latex]mm^2[/latex] of steel in tension and 628[latex]mm^2[/latex]
of steel in compression. The effective cover for compression steel is 50mm. Assume that
both tension and compression steel yield. The grades of concrete and steel used are M20
and Fe250 respectively. The stress lock parameters (rounded off to first two decimal
places) for concrete shall be as per IS 456:200. The depth of neutral axis is
solution: The resultant compressive force in the concrete is given by, [latex] C_{u c}=0.36 \mathrm{f}_{c k} b x_{u}[/latex] The resultant compressive force in the compression steel is given by, [latex] C_{u s}=\left(f_{s c}-0.45 f_{c k}\right) A_{s c}[/latex] The resultant tensile force in the tensile steel is given by, [latex] T_{u}=0.87 \mathrm{f} / \mathrm{A}_{s t}[/latex] we know that, [latex] \begin{array}{c} C_{u c}+C_{u s}=T_{u} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.36 f_{c k} b x_{u}+\left(f_{s c}-0.45 f_{c k}\right) A_{s c} =0.87 f_{r} A_{s t} \\ \Rightarrow \quad x_{u}=\frac{0.87 f_{y} A_{s t}-\left(f_{s c}-0.45 f_{c k}\right) A_{s c}}{0.36 f_{\alpha} b} \end{array}[/latex] Assuming [latex]f_{s c}=0.87 f_{y} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad x_{u}&=\frac{-(0.87 \times 250-0.45 \times 20) \times 628}{0.36 \times 20 \times 300} \\ \Rightarrow \quad x_{u}&=160.91 \mathrm{mm} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{But }x_{u, \max }&=0.53 d\text{ for }\mathrm{Fe} 250 \\ \therefore \quad x_{u, \max }&=0.53 \times 500=265 \mathrm{mm} \\ x_{u}& \lt x_{u, \max } ,\text{ hence the assumption}\\ f_{s c}&=0.87 \mathrm{f}_{y} \text{ is justified.} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 105 A rectangular concrete beam of width 120 mm and depth 200 mm is prestressed by pretensioning to a force of 150 kN at an eccentricity of 20 mm. The crosssectional
area of the prestressing steel is 187.5[latex]mm^{2}[/latex]. Take modulus of elasticity of steel and concrete as [latex]2.1\times 10^{5}[/latex]
 MPa and [latex]3.0\times 10^{4}[/latex]
 MPa respectively. The percentage loss of stress in the prestressing steel due to elastic deformation of concrete is
solution: Stress in concrete at the level of tendon, [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{c} &=\frac{P}{A}+\frac{P e^{2}}{I} \\ &=\frac{150 \times 10^{3}}{120 \times 200}+\frac{150 \times 20^{2} \times 12 \times 10^{3}}{120 \times 200^{3}} \\ &=7 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Loss of prestress due to elastic deformation, [latex] \Delta f_{s}=\frac{E_{s}}{E_{c}} \times f_{c}=\frac{2.1 \times 10^{5}}{3.0 \times 10^{4}} \times 7=49 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] Total stress in steel, [latex] f_{s}=\frac{P}{A_{s}}=\frac{150 \times 10^{3}}{187.5}=800 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Percentage loss of stress [latex] =\frac{\Delta f_{s}}{f_{s}} \times 100=\frac{49}{800} \times 100=6.125 \%[/latex]
