Question 108 A reinforced concrete beam of rectangular cross section of breadth 230 mm and
effective depth 400 mm is subjected to a maximum factored shear force of 120 kN. The grades of concrete, main steel and stirrup steel are M20, Fe415 and Fe250 respectively. For the area of main steel provided, the design shear strength [latex]\tau _c[/latex] as
per IS:456-2000 is 0.48 [latex]N/mm^2[/latex]. The beam is designed for collapse limit state. In addition, the beam is subjected to a torque whose factored value is 10.90 kNm. The stirrups have to be provided to carry a shear (kN) equal to
solution: Equivalent shear, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{u e} &=V_{u}+\frac{1.6 T_{u}}{b} \\ &=120+\frac{1.6 \times 10.90 \times 1000}{230} \\ &=120+75.83=195.83 \mathrm{kN} \\ v_{w} &=44.16 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad[/latex] Ultimate shear to be resisted by stirrups, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{u s} &=V_{u e}-V_{u c} \\ &=195.83-44.16=151.67 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 109 A reinforced concrete beam of rectangular cross section of breadth 230 mm and
 effective depth 400 mm is subjected to a maximum factored shear force of 120 kN. The grades of concrete, main steel and stirrup steel are M20, Fe415 and Fe250 respectively. For the area of main steel provided, the design shear strength [latex]\tau _c[/latex] as
per IS:456-2000 is 0.48 [latex]N/mm^2[/latex]. The beam is designed for collapse limit state. The spacing (mm) of 2-legged 8 mm stirrups to be provided is
solution: Ultimate design shear force, [latex] V_{u}=120 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] Ultimate shear capacity of concrete, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{u c} &=\tau_{c} b d \\ &=0.48 \times 230 \times 400=44.16 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Ultimate shear to be resisted by shear reinforcement, [latex] V_{u s}=V_{u}-V_{u c}=120-44.16=75.84 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] For vertical stirrups, spacing is given as [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{v} &=\frac{0.87 f_{y} A_{s v} d}{V_{u s}} \\ &=\frac{0.87 \times 250 \times 2 \times \pi \times(8)^{2} \times 400}{75.84 \times 10^{3} \times 4} \\ &=115.32 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 110 A pre-tensioned concrete member of section 200mm x 250mm contains tendons
of area 500 [latex]mm^{2}[/latex] at centre of gravity of the section. The prestress in the tendons is 1000 [latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex]. Assuming modular ratio as 10, the stress ([latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex]) in concrete is
solution:
Compressive force in steel [latex]=A_{s t} \times f_{s t} [/latex] [latex]
=500 \times 10^{3}=5 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{N}[/latex] Area of section in terms of concrete [latex]
\begin{array}{l}
=A+(m-1) A_{s t} \\
=(200 \times 250)+(10-1) \times 500 \\
=54500 \mathrm{mm}^{2}
\end{array}[/latex] [latex]
\therefore [/latex] Stress in concrete [latex]
=\frac{P}{A}=\frac{5 \times 10^{5}}{54500}=9.17 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex]

question:
Question 111 A reinforced concrete column contains longitudinal steel equal to 1 percent of net
cross-section are of the column. Assume modular ratio as 10. The loads carried
(using the elastic theory) by the longitudinal steel and the net area of concrete,
are [latex]P_{s}[/latex]
and[latex]P_{c}[/latex]
 respectively. The ratio [latex]P_{s}/P_{c}[/latex]
 expressed as per cent is
solution: If A is the net cross-sectional area of the column, [latex]A_{s t}[/latex] is the area of steel, [latex]A_{c}[/latex] is area of concrete, m is modular ratio and [latex]f_{c}[/latex] is stress in concrete, then. [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{s t}&=\frac{1}{100} \times A=0.01 A \\ A_{c}&=A-A_{s t}=A-0.01 A=0.99 A\\ \frac{P_{s}}{P_{c}} &=\frac{m A_{s t} f_{c}}{A_{c} \times f_{c}} \\ &=\frac{10 \times 0.01 A \times f_{c}}{0.99 A \times f_{c}} \times 100=10.10 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 112 Un-factored maximum bending moment at a section of a reinforced concrete
beam resulting form a frame analysis are 50, 80, 120 and 180 kNm under dead, live, wind and earthquake loads respectively. The design moment (kNm) as per IS:456-2000 for the limit state of collapse (flexure) is
solution: Wind and earthquake effects are not considered simultaneously. (i) Design moment when wind effect is considered [latex] \begin{aligned} &=1.2(\mathrm{DL}+\mathrm{LL}+\mathrm{WL}) \\ &=1.2(50+80+120) \\ &=300 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] (ii) Design moment when earthquake effect is considered [latex] \begin{aligned} &=1.2(\mathrm{DL}+\mathrm{LL}+\mathrm{EL}) \\ &=1.2(50+80+180) \\ &=372 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

 \tau_{b d}[/latex] should be less than permissible value, if it is

question:
Question 115 A single reinforced rectangular concrete beam has a width of 150 mm and an
effective depth of 330 mm. The characteristic compressive strength of concrete
is 20 MPa and the characteristic tensile strength of steel is 415 MPa. Adopt the
stress block for concrete as given in IS:456-2000 and take limiting value 
of depth of neutral axis as 0.48 times the effective depth of the beam The limiting area of tension steel in [latex]mm^{2}[/latex] is
solution: Moment of resistance [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.87 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{y}} A_{\mathrm{st}}\left(d-0.42 x_{\mathrm{ulm}}\right) \\ \Rightarrow\quad 45.07 \times 10^{6}&=0.87 \times 415 \times A_{\mathrm{st}} \\ &(330-0.42 \times 158.4) \\ \Rightarrow\quad A_{s t}&=473.82 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 116 A single reinforced rectangular concrete beam has a width of 150 mm and an
effective depth of 330 mm. The characteristic compressive strength of concrete
is 20 MPa and the characteristic tensile strength of steel is 415 MPa. Adopt the
stress block for concrete as given in IS:456-2000 and take limiting value 
of depth of neutral axis as 0.48 times the effective depth of the beam The limiting value of the moment of resistance of the beam in kN.m is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x_{u, \lim } &=0.48 d \\ &=0.48 \times 330=158.4 \mathrm{mm}\\ \therefore &\text{ Moment of resistance}\\ &=0.36 \mathrm{f}_{c k} b x_{u, \lim }\left(d-0.42 x_{u, \lim }\right) \\ &=0.36 \times 20 \times 150 \times 158.4 \\ &\quad(330-0.42 \times 158.4) \\ &=45.07 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 117 Consider the following statements : 1. Modulus of elasticity of concrete increases with increase in compressive strength of concrete. 2. Brittleness of concrete increases with decrease in compressive strength of concrete. 3. Shear strength of concrete increase with increase in compressive strength of concrete. The TRUE statements are
solution: 1. Modulus of elasticity of concrete, [latex] E=5000 \sqrt{f_{c k}}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] modulus of elasticity of concrete increases with increase in compressive strength of concrete. 2. Brittleness of high strength concrete is more as compared to low strength concrete. 3. Shear strength of concrete is directly a function of compressive strength of concrete, [latex] \tau_{\mathrm{c}} \propto f_{c k}[/latex]

question:
Question 118 A concrete beam of rectangular cross-section of size 120 mm (width) and 200
mm (depth) is prestressed by a straight tendon to an effective force of 150 kN at
an eccentricity of 20 mm (below the centroidal axis in the depth direction). The
stresses at the top and bottom fibres of the section are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma_{\mathrm{top}} &=\frac{P}{A}-\frac{P e}{Z} \\ &=\frac{150 \times 10^{3}}{120 \times 200}-\frac{150 \times 10^{3} \times 20 \times 6}{120 \times(200)^{2}} \\ &=6.25-3.75 \\ &=2.5 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}(\text { compression }) \\ \sigma_{\text {bottom }} &=\frac{P}{A}+\frac{P e}{Z}=6.25+3.75 \\ &=10 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \text { (compression) } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 119 The percentage loss of prestress due to anchorage slip of 3 mm in a concrete beam
of length 30 m which is post-tensioned by a tendon with an initial stress of 1200
[latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex] and modulus of elasticity equal to [latex]2.1 \times 10^{5} N/mm^{2}[/latex] is
solution: Loss of prestress due to anchorage slip [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\Delta L}{L} \times E_{s}=\frac{3 \times 10^{-3}}{30} \times 2.1 \times 10^{5} \\ &=21 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] % loss of prestress [latex] =\frac{21}{1200} \times 100=1.75 \%[/latex]

question:
Question 120 Consider the following statements : 1. The compressive strength of concrete decreases with increase in water-cement ratio of the concrete mix 2. Water is added to the concrete mix for hydration of cement and workability. 3. Creep and shrinkage of concrete are independent of the water-cement ratio
in the concrete mix. The TRUE statements are
solution:
1. With increase in water cement ratio of concrete 
mix, void ratio increases, hence compressive 
strength of concrete will decreases. 2. Main function of water in concrete is hydration

question:
Question 121 In the design of beams for the limit state of collapse in flexure as per IS:456-2000, 
let the maximum strain in concrete be limited to 0.0025 (in place of 0.0035). 
For this situation, consider a rectangular beam section with breadth as 250 mm, effective depth as 350 mm, area of tension steel as 1500 [latex]mm^2[/latex], and the
characteristic strength of concrete and steel as 30 MPa and 250 MPa respectively. At the limiting state of collapse in flexure, the force acting on the compression
zone of the section is
solution: In strain diagram, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{O E}{O A}&=\frac{0.002}{0.0025} \\ \Rightarrow \quad O E&=\frac{4}{5} x_{u} \\ \Rightarrow \quad O E&=0.8 x_{u} \\ \therefore A E&=x_{u}-0.8 x_{u}=0.2 x_{u} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad [/latex] Total compressive force, [latex] \begin{aligned} &= 0.45 t_{c k} \times 0.2 x_{u} \times b+\frac{2}{3} \\ & \times 0.45 f_{c k} \times 0.8 x_{u} \times b \\ &= 0.33 f_{c k} b x_{u} \end{aligned}[/latex] Actual NA depth, [latex] \begin{aligned} C&=T\\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.33 f_{c k} b x_{u}&=0.87 f_{y} A_{s t} \\ \Rightarrow \quad x_{u}&=\frac{0.87 \times 250 \times 1500}{0.33 \times 30 \times 250}=131.8 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Total compressive force, [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.33 \times 30 \times 250 \times 131.8 \\ &=326 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 122 In the design of beams for the limit state of collapse in flexure as per IS:456-2000, 
let the maximum strain in concrete be limited to 0.0025 (in place of 0.0035). 
For this situation, consider a rectangular beam section with breadth as 250 mm, effective depth as 350 mm, area of tension steel as 1500 [latex]mm^2[/latex], and the
characteristic strength of concrete and steel as 30 MPa and 250 MPa respectively. The depth of neutral axis for the balanced failure is
solution: From similar triangles [latex]\Delta OAB[/latex] and [latex]\Delta OCD[/latex], we have, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{x_{u, \lim }}{0.0025}&=\frac{d-x_{u, \lim }}{\frac{f_{y}}{1.15 E_{s}}+0.002}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{d-x_{u, \lim }}{x_{u, \lim }}&=\frac{\frac{f_{y}}{1.15 E_{s}}+0.002}{0.0025} \\ \Rightarrow \quad\frac{d}{x_{u, \lim }}&=1+\frac{\frac{0.87 \mathrm{f}_{y}}{E_{s}}+0.002}{0.0025} \\ \Rightarrow \quad\frac{d}{x_{u \min }}&=\frac{0.0045+\frac{0.87 f_{y}}{E_{s}}}{0.0025} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{d}{x_{\text {Ulim }}}&=\frac{0.0045 E_{s}+0.87 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{y}}}{0.0025 \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{s}}} \\ &\qquad \left[\because E_{s}=2 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{MPa}\right] \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{x_{U, \bmod }}{d}&=\frac{500}{900+0.87 f_{y}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad x_{u, \lim }&=\left[\frac{500}{900+0.87 \times 250}\right] \times 350 \\ \Rightarrow \quad x_{u, \lim}&=156.6 \mathrm{mm}=156 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 123 Consider the following statements : I. The width-to-thickness ratio limitations on the plate elements under
compression in steel members are imposed by IS:800-1984 in order to avoid
fabrication difficulties. II. In a doubly reinforced concrete beam, the strain in compressive
reinforcement is higher than the strain in the adjoining concrete. III. If a cantilever I-section supports slab construction all along its length
with sufficient friction between them, the permissible bending stress in
compression will be the same as that in tension. The TRUE statements are
solution:
The width to thickness ratio limitations on the plate 
elements under compression in steel members are 
imposed by IS 800 : 1984 in order to avoid 
buckling at local points. Statement (2) is wrong because strain in 
compression reinforcement and adjoning concrete 
is same to maintain compatibility.

question:
Question 124 As per IS:456-2000, consider the following statements I. The modular ratio considered in the working stress method depends on the type of steel used. II. There is an upper limit on the nominal shear stress in beams (even with
shear reinforcement) due to the possibility of crushing of concrete in
diagonal compression. II. A rectangular slab whose length is equal to its width may not be a two-way
slab for some support conditions. The TRUE statements are

Question 127 Assume straight line instead of parabola for stress-strain curve of concrete as
follows and partial factor of safety as 1.0. A rectangular under-reinforced concrete section of 300mm width and 500mm
effective depth is reinforced with 3 bars of grade Fe 415, each of 16mm
diameter. Concrete mix is M20. The depth of the neutral axis obtained as per IS:456-2000 differs from the depth
of neutral axis obtained in above question by
solution: As per IS 456: 2000, total compressive force [latex]=0.36 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{ck}} \mathrm{bx}_{\mathrm{u}} [/latex] and total tensile force [latex]=0.87 \mathrm{f}_{y} \mathrm{A}_{\mathrm{st}} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] For actual depth of neutral axis [latex] \begin{array}{c} 0.36 \mathrm{f}_{c k} b x_{u}=0.87 \mathrm{f}_{y} A_{\mathrm{st}} \\ \Rightarrow 0.36 \times 20 \times 300 \times x_{u} \\ \qquad =0.87 \times 415 \times 3 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(16)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow x_{u}=100.82 \simeq 101 \mathrm{mm} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Difference between the depth of neutral axis calculated as per given stress strain curve and the depth of neutral axis calculated as per IS 456: 2000 is [latex]=101-76=25 \mathrm{mm}[/latex]

question:
Question 128 Assume straight line instead of parabola for stress-strain curve of concrete as
follows and partial factor of safety as 1.0. A rectangular under-reinforced concrete section of 300mm width and 500mm
effective depth is reinforced with 3 bars of grade Fe 415, each of 16mm
diameter. Concrete mix is M20. The depth of the neutral axis from the compression fibre is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{A B}{A C}&=\frac{0.002}{0.0035} \\ &\text{[from assumed stress diagram]}\\ \Rightarrow\quad \frac{A B}{A C} &=\frac{4}{7} \\ \Rightarrow\quad A B &=\frac{4}{7} x_{U} \\ \text{But}\quad B C &=A C-A B \\ &=x_{U}-\frac{4}{7} x_{u}=\frac{3}{7} x_{u} \end{aligned} [/latex] Total compressive force [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.67 \mathrm{f}_{c k} \times \frac{3}{7} x_{u} \times b+\frac{0.67 f_{c k}}{2} \times \frac{4}{7} x_{u} \times b \\ &=0.48 \mathrm{f}_{c k} b x_{u} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total tensile force [latex]=0.87 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{y}} A_{\mathrm{st}} [/latex] For actual depth of neutral axis, Total compressive force = Total tensile force [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow 0.48 f_{c k} b x_{u}&=0.87 f_{y} A_{s t} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.48 &\times 20 \times 300 \times x_{u} \\ &=0.87 \times 415 \times 3 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(16)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow x_{u}&=75.84 \simeq 76 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 129 A rectangular column section of 250mmx400mm is reinforced with five steel
bars of grade Fe-500, each of 20 mm diameter. Concrete mix is M30. Axial load
on the column section with minimum eccentricity as per IS:456-2000 using limit
state method can be applied upto
solution: The axial load on the column can be given as [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{u} &=0.4 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{cK}} A_{c}+0.67 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{y}} A_{\mathrm{sc}} \\ A_{c} &=A_{g}-A_{\mathrm{sc}} \\ &=(250 \times 400)-\left[5 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(20)^{2}\right] \\ &=98429.20 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ f_{y} &=500 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ A_{s c} &=5 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(20)^{2}=1570.8 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \therefore \quad P_{u} &=(0.4 \times 30 \times 98429.20) \\ &=1707.37 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

shear stress ([latex]\tau _{ve}[/latex]) as calculated by using the design code turns out to be lesser than
the design shear strength ([latex]\tau _{c}[/latex]) of the concrete. The equivalent flexural moment [latex]\left (M_{eq} \right )[/latex]
 for designing the longitudinal tension steel is

question:
Question 136 At the limit state of collapse, an RC beam is subjected to flexural moment 200
kN-m, shear force 20 kN and torque 9 kN-m. The beam is 300 mm wide and has a
gross depth of 425 mm, with an effective cover of 25 mm. The equivalent nominal
shear stress ([latex]\tau _{ve}[/latex]) as calculated by using the design code turns out to be lesser than
the design shear strength ([latex]\tau _{c}[/latex]) of the concrete. The equivalent shear force [latex]\left (V_{c} \right )[/latex]
 is
solution: The equivalent shear force, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{c} &=V+1.6 \frac{T}{B} \\ &=20+\frac{1.6 \times 9}{300 \times 10^{-3}}=68 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 137 A simply supported prestressed concreted beam is 6 m long and 300 mm wide. Its
gross depth is 600 mm. It is prestressed by horizontal cable tendons at a uniform
eccentricity of 100 mm. The prestressing tensile force in the cable tendons is 1000
kN. Neglect the self weight of beam. The maximum normal compressive stress in
the beam at transfer is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P &=1000 \mathrm{kN} \\ Z &=\frac{b d^{2}}{6}=\frac{300 \times 600^{2}}{6} \\ &=18 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ e &=100 \mathrm{mm} \\ A &=300 \times 600=180000 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum compressive stress, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma &=\frac{P}{A}+\frac{P e}{Z} \\ &=\frac{1000 \times 10^{3}}{180000}+\frac{1000 \times 10^{3} \times 100}{18 \times 10^{6}} \\ &=11.11 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 138 An RC square footing of side length 2 m and uniform effective depth 200 mm
is provided for a [latex]300mm\times 300mm[/latex] column. The line of action of the vertical compressive load passes through the centroid of the footing as well as the column. If the magnitude of the load is 320 kN, the nominal transverse (one way) shear stress in the footing is
solution: Uniform pressure, [latex] p_{0}=\frac{P}{A}=\frac{320}{2 \times 2}=80 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] The critical section for shear is at a distance of d =200 mm from the face of the column [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{u} &=p_{0} B\left[\frac{1}{2}(B-b)-d\right] \\ &=80 \times 2 \times\left[\frac{1}{2}(2-0.3)-0.2\right] \\ &=104 \mathrm{kN}\\ \text{Shear stress,}\\ \tau_{u} &=\frac{V_{u}}{B d}=\frac{104 \times 10^{3}}{2 \times 10^{3} \times 200} \\ &=0.26 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 139 An RC short column with [latex]300mm\times 300mm[/latex] square cross-section is made of M20 grade concrete and has 4 numbers, 20 mm diameter longitudinal bars of Fe-415 steel. It is under the action of a concentric axial compressive load. Ignoring the reduction in the area of concrete due to steel bars, the ultimate axial load carrying capacity of the column is
solution:
The ultimate load carrying capacity of the column will be, [latex]
 \begin{aligned} P_{uz}=& 0.45 \mathrm{f}_{ck} A_{c}+0.75 f_{y} A_{sc} \\ &\ldots \text { [clause } 39.6 \mathrm{IS} 456: 2000] \\=& 0.45 \times 20 \times(300)^{2}+0.75 \times 415 \times 4 \\ & \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(20)^{2}=1201.13 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned} [/latex] It may be noted that the equation. [latex]
 P_{u}=0.4 f_{c k} A_{c}+0.67 f_{y} A_{sc} [/latex] cannot be used here because it is applicable only 
when minimum eccentricy does not exceed 0.05 D. 
Also, it is given in the problem that the column is 
under the action of a concentric axial load.

Question 142 A reinforced concrete beam, size 200 mm wide and 300 mm deep overall is simply
supported over a span of 3 m. It is subjected to two point loads P of equal
magnitude placed at middle third points. The two loads are gradually increased
simultaneously. Beam is reinforced with 2 HYSD bars of 16 mm diameter placed
at an effective cover of 40 mm on bottom face and nominal shear reinforcement.
The characteristic compressive strength and the bending tensile strength of the
concrete are 20.0 N/[latex]mm^2[/latex] and 2.2 N/[latex]mm^2[/latex] respectively. The theoretical failure load of the beam for attainment of limit state of collapse
in flexure is
solution: [latex]A_{s t}=2 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(16)^{2}=402.12 \mathrm{mm}^{2} [/latex] For limit state of collapse, [latex] \begin{aligned} x_{u} &=\frac{0.87 f_{y} A_{s}}{0.36 f_{c k} b} \\ &=\frac{0.87 \times 415 \times 402.12}{0.36 \times 20 \times 200} \\ &=100.8 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { But } x_{u, \lim} &=0.48 d=0.48 \times(300-40) \\ &=124.8 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { since, } \quad x_{u} & \lt x_{u, \lim} \end{aligned}[/latex] the section is under reinforced. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad M_{u}&=0.87 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{y}} A_{\mathrm{st}}\left(d-0.42 x_{\mathrm{U}}\right) \\ &= 0.87 \times 415 \times 402.12 \\ & \times(260-0.42 \times 100.8) \\ &= 31.6 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m}\\ \text{But } \quad M_{u}&=\frac{P L}{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{P \times 3}{3}&=31.6 \\ \Rightarrow \quad P&=31.6 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 143 A reinforced concrete beam, size 200 mm wide and 300 mm deep overall is simply
supported over a span of 3 m. It is subjected to two point loads P of equal
magnitude placed at middle third points. The two loads are gradually increased
simultaneously. Beam is reinforced with 2 HYSD bars of 16 mm diameter placed
at an effective cover of 40 mm on bottom face and nominal shear reinforcement.
The characteristic compressive strength and the bending tensile strength of the
concrete are 20.0 N/[latex]mm^2[/latex] and 2.2 N/[latex]mm^2[/latex] respectively. Ignoring the presence of tension reinforcement, the value of load P in kN when
the first flexure crack will develop in the beam is
solution: Bending tensile strength, [latex]\sigma_{b t}=2.2 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} [/latex] Characteristic compressive strength, [latex] f_{c k}=20 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Maximum stress in concrete, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{c b c} &=0.45 f_{c k}=0.45 \times 20 \\ &=9 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned} [/latex] Section modulus, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z &=\frac{b D^{2}}{6}=\frac{200 \times(300)^{2}}{6} \\ &=3 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{mm}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Maximum moment, [latex] \begin{aligned} M_{\operatorname{rrax}} &=Z \sigma_{b t}=3 \times 10^{6} \times 2.2 \\ &=6.6 \times 10^{6}=6.6 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m} \\ M_{\max } &=\frac{P L}{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{P \times 3}{3} &=6.6 \\ \Rightarrow \quad P &=6.6 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 144 A concrete column carries an axial load of 450 kN and a bending moment of 60
kNm at its base. An isolated footing of size 2mx3m, with 3m side along the plane of the
bending moment, is provided under the column. Centres of gravity of column and
footing coincide. The net maximum and the minimum pressures in kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] on soil under the footing are respectively
solution: Area of footing. [latex] A=2 \times 3=6 \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] Section modulus, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z &=\frac{b d^{2}}{6}=\frac{2 \times 3^{2}}{6}=3 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \therefore \quad \sigma &=\frac{P}{A} \pm \frac{M}{Z}=\frac{450}{6} \pm \frac{60}{3} \\ &=75 \pm 20 \\ \therefore \quad \sigma_{\max } &=95 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \text{and}\quad \sigma_{\min } &=55 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 146 Top ring beam of an Intze tank carries a hoop tension of 120 kN. The beam cross-section is 250 mm wide and 400 mm deep and it is reinforced with 4 bars of 20 mm diameter of Fe-415 grade. Molular ratio of the concrete is 10. The tensile stress in N/[latex]mm^{2}[/latex] in the concrete is
solution: The tensile stress in the concrete is given by, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{t} &=\frac{\text { Hoop tension }}{(b \times d)+(m-1) A_{s t}} \\ &=\frac{120 \times 10^{3}}{(250 \times 400)+(10-1) \times 4 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(20)^{2}} \\ &=1.07 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]
